classes_DependentPlace.name: DependentPlace
comment: A feature that is not part of its host, like a hole in a piece of cheese.
label: Dependent place

classes_Deposit.name: Deposit
comment: A role classifying an object ontop which others are put to e.g. store them, or to place them in a meaningful way for future activities.

classes_DepositedObject.name: DepositedObject
comment: An object placed ontop of another one.
label: Deposited object

classes_Deposition.name: Deposition
comment: The disposition to support objects.

classes_InformationAcquisition.name: InformationAcquisition
comment:
A mental task in which the executing agent acquires some information that was not immediately available to it before.
A synonym might be "Thinking".

Examples include recalling knowledge or inferring some information from other information.
label: Information acquisition

classes_Premise.name: Premise
comment: The role of an object that is used to infer some conclusion via some inference rules.
label: Premises

classes_DesignedComponent.name: DesignedComponent
comment: An object designed to be part or element of a larger whole.
label: Designed component

classes_FunctionalPart.name: FunctionalPart
comment: Parts of an agent or an artifact are considered as functional parts.
label: Functional part

classes_DesignedContainer.name: DesignedContainer
comment: An item designed to be able to hold some other items, preventing their free movement and/or protecting them from outside influence. Containers may be used for storage, or to obtain control over items that are otherwise hard to manipulate directly (e.g. liquids).
label: Designed container

classes_DesignedFurniture.name: DesignedFurniture
comment: An object used to make a room or building suitable for living or working.
label: Designed furniture

classes_DesignedTool.name: DesignedTool
comment: An item designed to enable some action, in which it will play an instrumental role.
label: Designed tool

classes_Destination.name: Destination
comment: A role classifying the location where an event or object is directed towards.

classes_Location.name: Location
comment: A role classifying a location of interest, often specified as a spatial relation between several objects, themselves usually classified by spatial relation roles.

classes_DestroyedObject.name: DestroyedObject
comment: An object that is detroyed.
label: Destroyed object

classes_Destruction.name: Destruction
comment:
A process by which a physical Entity is destroyed.

Note, most of the physical Entities we are concerned with are actually arrangements of many smaller physical Entities, so another way to look at this is that a 'Physical destruction' is a process by which an arrangement of physical Entities, which was previously itself considered a physical Entity, is changed to such an extent that it is no longer recognized as continuing to exist.
label: Destruction

classes_DetectedObject.name: DetectedObject
comment: An object that is detected.
label: Detected object

classes_DeviceState.name: DeviceState
comment: A quality belonging to a device which indicates its overall functional state.

classes_DeviceStateRange.name: DeviceStateRange
comment: This class defines the values that a device state can take.
label: Device state range

classes_DeviceTurnedOff.name: DeviceTurnedOff
comment: A value indicating a device is not in operation.
label: Device turned off

classes_DeviceTurnedOn.name: DeviceTurnedOn
comment: A value indicating a device is in operation.
label: Device turned on

classes_Dicing.name: Dicing
comment: A particular kind of cutting where the goal is to produce small pieces out of some object or material. Unlike slices, the pieces to be obtained do not have one or two dimensions being more prominent than others. "Dice", the pieces dicing results in, are approximately cubic.

classes_DirectedMotion.name: DirectedMotion
comment: A Motion that is considered to be toward a location or along a path. It is not important that the final location or path be the intention of some Agent, but it is considered that the important feature of this Motion is that it has a path and/or destination.
label: Directed motion

classes_UndirectedMotion.name: UndirectedMotion
comment: A Motion of a physical Entity for which a destination or path are unknown and/or considered irrelevant; the important aspect about this Motion is simply that it occurs, rather than where it is headed or how it proceeds towards it.
label: Undirected motion

classes_Dirty.name: Dirty
comment: A cleanliness region with values considered as dirty.

classes_Discourse.name: Discourse
comment: A mental task, in which two or more agents discuss some topic via multiple Illocutionary acts, which are part of this task.
label: Discourse

classes_Distancing.name: Distancing
comment: A task in which an Agent increases its distance from some location.

classes_Dreaming.name: Dreaming
comment: Any form of re-processing episodic memories for long-term memory by natural or aritifical agents.

classes_Driving.name: Driving
comment: A process type classifying a motion of a body that exists because this body is attached to and controls some other moving body, usually a vehicle.

classes_Flying.name: Flying
comment: A process type classifying a motion of a body that, through its own power, keeps itself aloft.

classes_Swimming.name: Swimming
comment: A motion of some body through water. The body provides the power for the motion.

classes_Walking.name: Walking
comment: An agent, under its own power, moves over some solid surface.

classes_Dropping.name: Dropping
comment:
The dropped object falls mainly under the influence of gravity. However, an agent may also drop something during navigation. The difference to 'Throwing' is that there is no 'Limb motion' which is a constitiuent of the action.

'Dropping' is intentional. Dropping by accident may not has a phase to release the grasp. It could be that the grasp was not strong enough and the objects "slips" away.

classes_Placing.name: Placing
comment: Distinguished from Positioning in that this task is more about placing an object at a functionally specified location (e.g., place the cup on the table) as opposed to positioning an object at a location defined by coordinates or a region of coordinates (position the cup at xyz).

classes_ESTSchemaTheory.name: ESTSchemaTheory
comment:
A schematic theory that describes the existence of an entity.

Developmental psychology posits that "object permanence" (the assumption that physical objects keep existing even when the agent doesn't perceive them, which consequently informs reasoning about where an object should be, even when perception of it is lost) is a cognitive ability that is not, at least in the very young human child, immediately manifest. Rather, it seems learned via interaction, and usually is among an infant's cognitive repertoire by age 2.

In SOMA, we represent this ability of a cognitive agent as an ability to generate and maintain ESTSchemaTheories. Each instance of such a theory refers to one particular physical object, the one that the instance of the ESTSchemaTheory asserts to exist.

Because each instance of an ESTSchemaTheory refers to a single object, ESTSchemaTheories are not associated to any relation between OWL individuals.
label: EST schema theory

classes_ExistingObjectRole.name: ExistingObjectRole
comment:
A role that requires of its filler simply to exist, unlike other roles that may demand e.g. agentive or instrumental participation in some executable schema or plan (AgentRole and Instrument respectively).

The intention behind such a simple role is to have a way to represent, in a schematic formalism used to describe some scene, that an object is present. In particular, the schema used to convey this information is the ESTSchemaTheory, which has ExistingObjectRole as its sole defined role.
label: Existing object role

classes_Effort.name: Effort
comment: A parameter describing the amount of force to be exerted by some actuator.

classes_EnclosedObject.name: EnclosedObject
comment: An object included within the spatial boundaries of another object.
label: Enclosed object

classes_Enclosing.name: Enclosing
comment: The disposition of an object (the container) to contain other objects by enclosing them to prevent their free movement.

classes_EndEffectorPositioning.name: EndEffectorPositioning
comment: A task in which an Agent places its end effectors at particular poses.
label: End effector positioning

classes_Manipulating.name: Manipulating
comment:
Tasks where the goal is to move the prehensile effectors, ie. hands, of an agent so as to achieve some spatial or functional relation with some manipulated object. 

Spatial relations refer to positioning the hands in certain ways relative to the manipulated object, for example nearing or distancing them, or aligning them with some relevant axis.

Functional relations here refer to interactions between the hands and manipulated object which constrain the possible behavior of the object. Examples of functional relations in manipulation are support and kinematic control.

Note that manipulation tasks are usually performed with the intention of moving an object in some way, so there is a large conceptual overlap between Manipulating and Actuating.

However these concepts are nonetheless distinguished in what they "profile", ie. what they focus on as particularly important.

Actuating profiles the movement of the object itself.

Manipulating profiles the movement of the hands and the functional relations, such as kinematic control, they establish with the manipulated object.

Note: we employ Manipulating here in its literal, original sense, of using hands for some purpose, and not in the metaphorical sense of exerting psychological pressure on someone.

classes_ExcludedObject.name: ExcludedObject
comment: An object that is not contained in something. This is meant very general and includes, e.g., elements excluded from a set, or things that are spatially excluded from the boundaries of some object.
label: Excluded object

classes_ExecutableFile.name: ExecutableFile
comment:
An Executable File, sometimes simply referred to as an executable or binary, causes a computer "to perform indicated tasks according to encoded instructions", as opposed to a data file that must be interpreted (parsed) by a program to be meaningful.

The exact interpretation depends upon the use. "Instructions" is traditionally taken to mean machine code instructions for a physical CPU. In some contexts, a file containing scripting instructions (such as bytecode) may also be considered executable.
label: Executable File

classes_Executable_Code.name: Executable_Code
comment: Executable Code is Code that when compiled / interpreted, has some clear entrance point and can be executed. Note the difference to an Executable File, which is the file that contains such (compiled) code.
label: Executable Code

classes_ExecutableFormat.name: ExecutableFormat
comment: An Executable Format is a File Format that allows computers to directly execute the content. Examples are MZ (DOS) or COFF.
label: Executable Format

classes_SchematicTheory.name: SchematicTheory
comment:
A theory used to describe, analyze, and reason with the meaning of a linguistic message.

Note that such theories are useful both when analyzing an actual linguistic production, and when creating a linguistic production to describe some observed experience.
label: Schematic theory

classes_ExecutableSoftware.name: ExecutableSoftware
comment: Executable Software is Software that can directly be executed, in comparison to a Software Library, which might only contain functionality via interfaces, but offers no execution entry point.
label: Executable Software

classes_RelationAdjacentRole.name: RelationAdjacentRole
comment: A role classifying an object participating in some relation, e.g. a participant in a spatial relation or a linguistic fragment in a rhetorical relation to another.
label: Relation adjacent role

classes_ExperiencerRole.name: ExperiencerRole
comment: A role used in frame semantics to classify agents performing perception actions, or being the subjects affected by some biological process.
label: Experiencer role

classes_ExtractedObject.name: ExtractedObject
comment: An object that is removed from a container or system.
label: Extracted object

classes_PhysicalQuality.name: PhysicalQuality
comment: Any aspect of an entity that is dependent on its physical manifestation.
label: Physical quality

classes_FailedAttempt.name: FailedAttempt
comment: A description of a failed attempt to achieve some goal.
label: Failed attempt

classes_Unsuccessfulness.name: Unsuccessfulness
comment: A description of a situation with a goal that was not or not fully achieved by some system.

classes_FaultySoftware.name: FaultySoftware
comment: A description of a situation where some software has a bug.
label: Faulty software

classes_SoftwareDiagnosis.name: SoftwareDiagnosis
comment: A diagnosis of the software of a system.
label: Software diagnosis

classes_PhysicalAcquiring.name: PhysicalAcquiring
comment:
The goal of this task is to make some object usable for other tasks, by possibly changing its physical state. Usually, it overlaps some task that describes the manner in which an object is obtained.

The prototypical example of PhysicalAcquiring is picking up an object.

Note that buying an object is NOT PhysicalAcquiring. Buying, or ownership transfer in general, also involves an adjustment in social structures describing ownership.
label: Physical acquiring

classes_Finger.name: Finger
comment: A limb used for grasping objects.

classes_Hand.name: Hand
comment: A prehensile effector including palm, fingers, and thumb.

classes_FixedJoint.name: FixedJoint
comment: A joint that cannot move, designed to fixiate links.
label: Fixed joint

classes_MovableJoint.name: MovableJoint
comment: A joint where the two connected links can move relative to each other in some dimension.
label: Movable joint

classes_Flipping.name: Flipping
comment: The task in which the agent turns an object over by using a tool or by manipulating

classes_FloatingJoint.name: FloatingJoint
comment: A joint that allows motion for all 6 degrees of freedom.
label: Floating joint

classes_Fluid.name: Fluid
comment: A substance with a consistency such that it can flow or diffuse.

classes_Substance.name: Substance
comment:
Any PhysicalBody that has not necessarily specified (designed) boundaries, e.g. a pile of trash, some sand, etc. 
In this sense, an artistic object made of trash or a dose of medicine in the form of a pill would be a FunctionalSubstance, and a DesignedArtifact, since its boundaries are specified by a Design; aleatoric objects that are outcomes of an artistic process might be still considered DesignedArtifact(s), and Substance(s).
label: Substance

classes_MovedObject.name: MovedObject
comment: An object undergoing location change.
label: Moved object

classes_Focusing.name: Focusing
comment: The mental task to center the attention to some subject.
label: Focusing

classes_Foolishness.name: Foolishness
comment: A description of foolish behavior.

classes_ForgettingIncorrectInformation.name: ForgettingIncorrectInformation
comment: A mental task in which the executing agent aims to correct its present information by deleting an incorrect information.
label: Forgetting incorrect information

classes_InformationDismissal.name: InformationDismissal
comment:
A mental task in which the executing agent dismisses some information.

An example is forgetting some knowledge.
label: Information dismissal

classes_ForgettingIrrelevantInformation.name: ForgettingIrrelevantInformation
comment: A mental task in which the executing agent aims to clean up its present information by deleting an irrelevant information.
label: Forgetting irrelevant information

classes_Language.name: Language
comment:
A Language is a structured System for communication.

From Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language
label: Language

classes_Item.name: Item
comment: A role played by a non-agentive object operated on by an action.

classes_FunctionalDesign.name: FunctionalDesign
comment: The design of an object from functionality point of view. A functional design is useful to develop complex modular objects with components that have a specific purpose, and can function with minimum side effect on other components of that object.
label: Functional Design

classes_FunctionalDiagnosis.name: FunctionalDiagnosis
comment: An internal diagnosis of a system.
label: Functional diagnosis

classes_PhysicalBody.name: PhysicalBody
comment: Physical bodies are PhysicalObject(s), for which we tend to neutralize any possible artifactual character. They can have several granularity levels: geological, chemical, physical, biological, etc.
label: Physical body

classes_LocatumRole.name: LocatumRole
comment: Denotes the object with primary focal prominence in a spatial or spatio-temporal schema. Terminological variants that appear in the literature on cognitive linguistics include Figure (Talmy 1983) and Trajector (Langacker 1986).
label: Locatum role

classes_RelatumRole.name: RelatumRole
comment: Denotes the reference object in a spatial or spatio-temporal schema, i.e. the object with secondary focal prominence. Terminological variants: Ground (Talmy 1983), Landmark (Langacker 1986).
label: Relatum role

classes_GetTaskParameter.name: GetTaskParameter
comment: A task in which an Agent computes some parameter relevant for another task.
label: Get task parameter

classes_Planning.name: Planning
comment: A Mental task in which the Agent endeavours to create a sequence of actions for itself which, if followed, will bring about a particular state of affairs in the world. This particular state of affairs is known to the agent and is often called the goal state of the planning action. Planning commits itself to feasibility: the Agent attempts to find a sequence of actions that it believes it will actually be able to perform.

classes_GraphDatabase.name: GraphDatabase
comment: A Graph Database is a Database that uses graph structures for semantic queries with nodes, edges, and properties to represent and store data.
label: Graph database

classes_GraphQueryLanguage.name: GraphQueryLanguage
comment: A Query Language that is designed for communication with some Graph Database.
label: Graph query language

classes_QueryLanguage.name: QueryLanguage
comment:
Query languages, are Computer languages used to make queries in databases and information systems (Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_language).

Note that despite their name, Query languages typically come with syntax and semantic to not only ask for information, but also provide them, e.g., via SQL Update. In that sense, the term "query" from above refers to any formal object of information exchange with a database.
label: Query language

classes_GraspTransfer.name: GraspTransfer
comment: A task in which an Agent switches which of its end effectors holds an object.
label: Grasp transfer

classes_Grasping.name: Grasping
comment: A task in which an Agent uses its end effectors to grasp an object, thus gaining kinematic control over it.

classes_Graspability.name: Graspability
comment: The disposition of an object (e.g. the handle) to afford grasping the object.

classes_Releasing.name: Releasing
comment: A task in which an agent relinquishes its kinematic control over an object, typically by releasing it from its grasp.

classes_GraspingMotion.name: GraspingMotion
comment: A process type classifying a motion by which some end effector acquires kinematic control over some other object.
label: Grasping motion

classes_IntermediateGrasp.name: IntermediateGrasp
comment: A kind of grasp that acquires kinematic control over the gripped object, but without attempting to achieve either strong holding force nor precision of subsequent movement of the gripped object.
label: Intermediate grasp

classes_PowerGrasp.name: PowerGrasp
comment: An Agent grasps an object, and focuses on obtaining a strong grasping force upon it, resulting in a grasp able to resist significant outside disturbances. This is useful when using tools with which to later exert force on other things, e.g. when hammering nails.
label: Power grasp

classes_PrecisionGrasp.name: PrecisionGrasp
comment: An Agent grasps an object, and focuses on obtaining precise kinematic control over it. This is useful for then following precise movements, e.g. when writing.
label: Precision grasp

classes_PrehensileMotion.name: PrehensileMotion
comment: A motion of a prehensile effector.
label: Prehensile motion

classes_ReleasingMotion.name: ReleasingMotion
comment: A motion by which a prehensile effector relinquishes kinematic control over an object.
label: Releasing motion

classes_GreenColor.name: GreenColor
comment: A color region with dominant green color.
label: Green color

classes_Gripper.name: Gripper
comment: A mechanical device that grasps and holds things.

classes_PrehensileEffector.name: PrehensileEffector
comment: An effector used to grasp objects, such as a hand of a human, or the long prehensile tail of a monkey.
label: Prehensile effector

classes_HardwareDiagnosis.name: HardwareDiagnosis
comment: A diagnosis of the hardware of a system.
label: Hardware diagnosis

classes_TechnicalDiagnosis.name: TechnicalDiagnosis
comment: A functional diagnosis of a technical system.
label: Technical diagnosis

classes_HasQualityRegion.name: HasQualityRegion
comment: The relation between an individual quality and a region.
todo(DB): added for NEEMs (quale change), but not sure yet about it...
label: Has quality region

classes_Head.name: Head
comment: A functional part of the body responsible for carrying high bandwidth sensors, i.e., camera.

classes_HeadMovement.name: HeadMovement
comment: The Agent moves a part of their body carrying high-bandwidth sensors such as cameras. The movement of other body parts is not significant.
todo: (Mihai:) This seems too specific, given the "Directed"/"Undirected motion" categories.

classes_HeadTurning.name: HeadTurning
comment: A process type classifying a motion of an Agent's head such that the direction this head faces changes relative to the facing direction of the Agent's body as a whole.

classes_Holding.name: Holding
comment: A task by which an Agent keeps an object over which it has kinematic control, typically via grasping, at some specified pose.

classes_HostRole.name: HostRole
comment:
In the Plug-in-Host pattern, a Host application provides services which the Plug-in can use, including a way for Plug-ins to register themselves with the Host application and a protocol for the exchange of data withPplug-ins. Plug-ins depend on the services provided by the host application and do not usually work by themselves. Conversely, the host application operates independently of the plug-ins, making it possible for end-users to add and update plug-ins dynamically without needing to make changes to the host application.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plug-in_(computing)
label: Host role

classes_PluginSpecification.name: PluginSpecification
comment: The Specification of a Plugin interface defines how a Host and a Plug-in function together and exchange information.
label: Plugin Specification

classes_Human-readable_Programming_Langu.name: Human-readable_Programming_Language
comment: A Programming language like Java, Python etc. but not binary machine code.
label: Human-readable Programming Language

classes_Source_Code.name: Source_Code
comment: The Source Code itself (the specific set of instruction in a human-readable Programming Language), not the file that it is contained in nor the implemented algorithm!
label: Source code

classes_HumanActivityRecording.name: HumanActivityRecording
comment: An episode in which one or more human beings perform an activity and are recorded doing so.

classes_RecordedEpisode.name: RecordedEpisode
comment: An episode which has been recorded.

classes_Imagining.name: Imagining
comment: A Mental task in which the Agent constructs a mental representation of a possible world. An Agent performing an Imagining activity does not aim to construct a representation that aspires to be faithful to some past, present, or future state of affairs of the actual world it is embodied in.

classes_Impediment.name: Impediment
comment: The disposition of an object (the obstacle) to prohibit certain ways of entering or leaving a space or group. An example is a doorstopper constraining a door, prohibiting it to enter the area behind it.

classes_Obstacle.name: Obstacle
comment: An object used to restrict access to a protected space or group.

classes_RestrictedObject.name: RestrictedObject
comment: An object with restrictions to access something.
label: Restricted object

classes_Inability.name: Inability
comment: A description of a situation with a goal that some system is unable to achieve.

classes_IncompatibleSoftware.name: IncompatibleSoftware
comment: A description of a situation where two software systems are incompatible with each other.
label: Incompatible software

classes_InductiveReasoning.name: InductiveReasoning
comment:
A task in which the Agent endeavors to accumulate confidence in some general statement about the world, by gathering instances in which this general statement appears to apply. Note that perfect confidence can never be guaranteed by induction.

Induction is often described as a move from many "specifics" (swan A is white, swan B is white, swan C is white, ...) to the "general" (all swans are white).
label: Inductive resoning

classes_Infeasibility.name: Infeasibility
comment: A description of a situation with a goal that is impossible to achieve in some situational context.

classes_InferenceRules.name: InferenceRules
comment: The role of an object that is used to derive a conclusion from some premises.
label: Inference rules

classes_InformationRetrieval.name: InformationRetrieval
comment:
A mental task in which an Agent recalls some knowledge that has been memorized previously.

Examples include a human remembering some information or a computer retrieving knowledge from a database.

The difference to Remembering is that for this Task, we are concerned with knowledge about a previous world state. Memory Retrieval is more general in the sense that it also includes the retrieval of learned facts and rules.
label: Information retrieval

classes_InformationStorage.name: InformationStorage
comment:
A mental task in which the executing agent persists some information for later recall, if necessary.

An example is learning new knowledge.
label: Information storage

classes_StoredObject.name: StoredObject
comment: An object being stored into some other object, usually inside a container.

classes_InsertedObject.name: InsertedObject
comment: An object inserted into another object.
label: Inserted object

classes_Insertion.name: Insertion
comment: The disposition of an object (the container) to contain other objects that can be inserted into the container through a portal.

classes_Instructions.name: Instructions
comment: The role of a plan to follow during an execution task.
label: Instructions

classes_Interpreting.name: Interpreting
comment: A task in which an Agent interpretes some information, e.g., makes sense of some incoming message or its visible surroundings.
label: Interpreting

classes_InterrogativeClause.name: InterrogativeClause
comment:
A clause which makes a request, typically information, of some agent.

Note that in a semantic sense such clauses always request information, but in a pragmatic sense they can be used to convey commands or requests for action, such as e.g. "can you close the door?" The question is not just a request for information about ability, but a request to perform a task.
label: Interrogative clause

classes_Introspecting.name: Introspecting
comment: A mentalk task in which an Agent gathers and processes information about its own mental tasks via, e.g., Meta Reasoning.
label: Introspecting

classes_KineticFrictionAttribute.name: KineticFrictionAttribute
comment: Friction that occurs when two touching objects are moving relative to each other.
label: Kinetic friction attribute

classes_KinoDynamicData.name: KinoDynamicData
comment: An InformationObject containing data about how a physical object is put together such that its parts may move relative to each other, and what the physical characteristics of those parts are.
label: Kino-dynamic data

classes_KnowledgeRepresentationLanguage.name: KnowledgeRepresentationLanguage
comment: A Knowledge Representation Language is a Language with fixed semantics and syntax to describe some knowledge. Examples are JSON and the different OWL Profiles.
label: Knowledge Representation Language

classes_Text.name: Text
comment:
Any Information Object defined using a Language that, when realized through a symbolic writing system, can be read and made sense of.

One may define Text as anything that can be made sense of, including e.g., Speech or Paintings.

However, the argument can be made that Speech or Paintings are not considered Text as they cannot be EXACTLY realized by a symbolic writing system: Speech may loose punctuation, Paintings their original appearance.
On the other hand, this might not be true as both could be encoded in a binary format that can be interpreted using a language (eg., mp3, png).
label: Text

classes_Leaning.name: Leaning
comment: An Agent pitches its body in some direction.

classes_PosturalMoving.name: PosturalMoving
comment:
The Agent changes or takes an overall configuration of its body but is otherwise not significantly affecting other objects nor moving a significant amount from its original location.

Posture changes may take place as part of other actions, for example turning when walking.

classes_Learning.name: Learning
comment:
The mental task of storing information for later use.

This is more general than memorizing, as the later only captures declarative knowledge.
label: Learning

classes_Leg.name: Leg
comment: A limb on which an agent walks or stands.

classes_LimbMotion.name: LimbMotion
comment: An Agent moves its limbs in some way.
label: Limb motion

classes_Linkage.name: Linkage
comment: The disposition of an object (the linked object) to establish a connection with others by being linked together.

classes_LinkedObject.name: LinkedObject
comment: An object that is linked to some other object.
label: Linked object

classes_LinkageState.name: LinkageState
comment: Classifies States in which two objects are in a rigid connection, such that the movement of one determines the movement of the other.
label: Linkage state

classes_SpatioTemporalRole.name: SpatioTemporalRole
comment: Roles that classify entities which locate an event or object in space and time.
label: Spatio-temporal role

classes_SpatialRelationRole.name: SpatialRelationRole
comment: Roles classifying entities participating in some spatial relation.
label: Spatial relation role

classes_LocutionaryAction.name: LocutionaryAction
comment:
A Locutionary Act is the performance of an utterance (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locutionary_act).

We additionally require a Locutionary Act to be performed by an Agent, not an Actor - this is what sets it apart from a Communication Action.
label: Locutionary action

classes_LookingAt.name: LookingAt
comment: better: Gazing

classes_LookingFor.name: LookingFor
comment: A task by which an Agent uses its perception apparatus to check for the presence of an object in some specified area.
label: Looking for

classes_Lowering.name: Lowering
comment: A task in which an Agent reduces the elevation at which they hold an item.

classes_PhysicalAction.name: PhysicalAction
comment: An action performed by an agent by using its body in some way to interact with the physical world, e.g., through manipulation of objects, or by changing the posture.
label: Physical action

classes_Markup_Language.name: Markup_Language
comment:
Markup refers to data included in an electronic document which is distinct from the document's content in that it is typically not included in representations of the document for end users, for example on paper or a computer screen, or in an audio stream. Markup is often used to control the display of the document or to enrich its content to facilitate automated processing. A markup language is a set of rules governing what markup information may be included in a document and how it is combined with the content of the document in a way to facilitate use by humans and computer programs.

From Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markup_language
label: Markup Language

classes_Material.name: Material
comment: The matter from which a thing is made.

classes_MedicalDiagnosis.name: MedicalDiagnosis
comment: A functional diagnosis of an organism.
label: Medical diagnosis

classes_Organism.name: Organism
comment: A physical objects with biological characteristics, typically that organisms can self-reproduce.
label: Organism

classes_Memorizing.name: Memorizing
comment:
An atomic mental task in which an Agent saves some (declarative) information for later retrieval.

Examples include a student learning vocabularies or a computer saving some information to a database.
label: Memorizing

classes_MentalAction.name: MentalAction
comment:
An Event construed as the Agent participant affecting Entities that are representations of actual or potential Entities or Events in the physical world in which the Agent is embodied. These representations are maintained by the Agent participant in the 'Mental action' event.

One could argue Mental actions are all Physical actions, because anything the Agent may use to maintain such representations will be physical things, However, we make this distinction because for Mental actions it is less important to consider the physical support of the representation and how it changes, and more important to track how the information content of the representation changes.
label: Mental action

classes_MeshShape.name: MeshShape
comment: A solid geometrical figure described in a mesh file.
label: Mesh shape

classes_MeshShapeData.name: MeshShapeData
comment: An InformationObject containing data about the geometry of a physical object.
label: Mesh-shape data

classes_MetaCognitionEvaluationTopic.name: MetaCognitionEvaluationTopic
comment: A topic used while an Agent describes its own cognitive processes and acions to evaluate them according to some metric.
label: Meta cognition evaluation topic

classes_MetaCognitionTopic.name: MetaCognitionTopic
comment: A topic for a description that an Agent might make of its own cognitive processes and actions.

classes_MetaCognitionMemoryTopic.name: MetaCognitionMemoryTopic
comment: A topic used while an Agent describes its own cognitive processes and actions, and which covers descriptions of what memories are involved in them.
label: Meta cognition memory topic

classes_MetaCognitionPlanningTopic.name: MetaCognitionPlanningTopic
comment: A topic used while an Agent describes the planning it does for its own cognitive processes and actions.
label: Meta cognition planning topic

classes_ThinkAloudTopic.name: ThinkAloudTopic
comment: A topic relevant for a think-aloud communication.
label: Think aloud topic

classes_MetacognitiveControlling.name: MetacognitiveControlling
comment: The concious or subconcious task to control the own mental processes, e.g., evaluating them and instructing the own mind to shift attention.
label: Metacognitive controlling

classes_MetacognitiveMonitoring.name: MetacognitiveMonitoring
comment: The task to label the processes and states of the own mind, e.g., to interprete the feeling of knowing an information but not being able to retrieve it at the moment as a tip-of-the-tongue event.
label: Metacognitive monitoring

classes_Mixing.name: Mixing
comment: A task by which an Agent combines several entities, such that the combination is difficult or in practice impossible to reverse.

classes_MixingTheory.name: MixingTheory
comment: A schematic theory about how an agent can mix a fluid or particulate object.
label: Mixing theory

classes_MonitoringJointState.name: MonitoringJointState
comment: A task in which the Agent keeps track of the physical state of its joints, e.g. their positions, velocities, efforts.
label: Monitoring joint state

classes_Proprioceiving.name: Proprioceiving
comment: A task in which the Agent gathers and interprets sensor information about itself.

classes_MovingAway.name: MovingAway
comment: A process type classifying a motion by which some Agent puts distance between itself and another object or location.

classes_MovingTo.name: MovingTo
comment: A task in which an Agent moves towards a location.

classes_Natural_Language.name: Natural_Language
comment:
A Natural Language is any language that has evolved naturally in humans through use and repetition without conscious planning or premeditation.

From Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language
label: Natural Language

classes_Natural_Language_Text.name: Natural_Language_Text
comment: A Text in a Natural Language.
label: Natural language text

classes_Ontology.name: Ontology
comment:
An ontology encompasses a representation, formal naming, and definition of the categories, properties, and relations between the concepts, data, and entities that substantiate one, many, or all domains of discourse. More simply, an ontology is a way of showing the properties of a subject area and how they are related, by defining a set of concepts and categories that represent the subject.

From Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontology_(information_science)

classes_Ontology_Language.name: Ontology_Language
comment:
An Ontology Language is a Knowledge Representation Language to describe knowledge about properties of a subject area and how they are related, by defining a set of concepts and categories that represent the subject using logic. Examples are the different OWL Profiles.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontology_(information_science)
label: Ontology Language

classes_Option.name: Option
comment: The Role of objects that are used, e.g., in Selecting Tasks.
label: Option

classes_FormalEntity.name: FormalEntity
comment:
Entities that are formally defined and are considered independent from the social context in which they are used. They cannot be localized in space or time. Also called 'Platonic entities'.
Mathematical and logical entities are included in this class: sets, categories, tuples, costants, variables, etc.
Abstract formal entities are distinguished from information objects, which are supposed to be part of a social context, and are localized in space and time, therefore being (social) objects.
For example, the class 'Quark' is an abstract formal entity from the purely set-theoretical perspective, but it is an InformationObject from the viewpoint of ontology design, when e.g. implemented in a logical language like OWL.
Abstract formal entities are also distinguished from Concept(s), Collection(s), and Description(s), which are part of a social context, therefore being SocialObject(s) as well.
For example, the class 'Quark' is an abstract FormalEntity from the purely set-theoretical perspective, but it is a Concept within history of science and cultural dynamics.

These distinctions allow to represent two different notions of 'semantics': the first one is abstract and formal ('formal semantics'), and formallyInterprets symbols that are about entities whatsoever; for example, the term 'Quark' isAbout the Collection of all quarks, and that Collection isFormalGroundingFor the abstract class 'Quark' (in the extensional sense). 
The second notion is social, localized in space-time ('social semantics'), and can be used to interpret entities in the intensional sense. For example, the Collection of all quarks isCoveredBy the Concept 'Quark', which is also expressed by the term 'Quark'.
label: Formal entity

classes_Singleton.name: Singleton
comment: A 'Set' that contains exactly one member.

classes_Orienting.name: Orienting
comment: A task in which an Agent adjusts the orientation of an object.

classes_Positioning.name: Positioning
comment: A task in which an Agent places an object at a particular position.

classes_Origin.name: Origin
comment: A role classifying the location where an event or object originated.

classes_ParkingArms.name: ParkingArms
comment: A task by which an Agent arranges its arms in such a way so as to minimize opportunities for collision while moving through the environment.
label: Parking arms

classes_PhaseTransition.name: PhaseTransition
comment: An EventType that classifies processes by which matter changes from some distinguishable phase to another. We will use this to refer to the classical phase transitions between Solid, Liquid, Gaseous, Plasma etc. phases.
label: Phase transition

classes_PhysicalAccessibility.name: PhysicalAccessibility
comment: Classifies States in which an item is placed in a container or protected by a protector, but the placement of the item and container is such that a, usually agentive, accessor may nevertheless reach the item in order to perform a task.
label: Physical accessibility

classes_PhysicalBlockage.name: PhysicalBlockage
comment: Classifies States in which an object, in general called restrictor, blocks access to an item. A usually agentive accessor, whose access is blocked, may be specified.
label: Physical blockage

classes_PhysicalExistence.name: PhysicalExistence
comment: A State in which an Entity is said to exist in the physical world.
label: Physical Existince

classes_PhysicalState.name: PhysicalState
comment: A State describing how Entities in the physical world relate to each other.
label: Physical state

classes_PhysicsProcess.name: PhysicsProcess
comment: A process involving physical objects and phenomena which does not change the chemical constituency of the affected objects.
label: Physical process

classes_PlacingTheory.name: PlacingTheory
comment: A schematic theory of how an agent can place a patient at a particular goal location.
label: Placing theory

classes_PlanarJoint.name: PlanarJoint
comment: A joint that allows motion in a plane perpendicular to an axis.
label: Planar joint

classes_PluginRole.name: PluginRole
comment:
In the Plug-in-Host pattern, a Host application provides services which the Plug-in can use, including a way for Plug-ins to register themselves with the Host application and a protocol for the exchange of data withPplug-ins. Plug-ins depend on the services provided by the host application and do not usually work by themselves. Conversely, the host application operates independently of the plug-ins, making it possible for end-users to add and update plug-ins dynamically without needing to make changes to the host application.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plug-in_(computing)
label: Plugin role

classes_Pourable.name: Pourable
comment: The disposition of a fluid or substance which makes it possible to pour it out of a container and into or onto other objects.

classes_PouredObject.name: PouredObject
comment: An object being poured into or onto some other object. A role of some fluid or substance that is the patient of pouring task.
label: Poured object

classes_Pouring.name: Pouring
comment: A task in which an agent lets liquid substance to flow out of an object. The agent has a kinematic control over the object.

classes_PouringInto.name: PouringInto
comment: The task in which the agent pours the substance into another object.
label: Pouring into

classes_PouringOnto.name: PouringOnto
comment: The task in which an agent pours the substance on top of an object
label: Pouring onto

classes_Prediction.name: Prediction
comment: A Mental task in which the Agent endeavours to construct a representation of a future state of the world. Prediction commits itself to some degree of accuracy: the Agent believes that eventually something similar to the predicted state will come to pass.
label: Predicting

classes_Prospecting.name: Prospecting
comment: A Mental task in which an Agent endeavours to construct a representation of a future state of affairs of the world it is embodied in.

classes_SocialRelation.name: SocialRelation
comment: Any social relationship
label: Social relation

classes_PreferenceRegion.name: PreferenceRegion
comment: The 'Region' of 'Preference's, containing all possible 'Order's between all possible 'Situation's.
label: Preference region

classes_SocialObjectAttribute.name: SocialObjectAttribute
comment: Any Region in a dimensional space that is used to represent some characteristic of a SocialObject, e.g. judgment values, social scalars, statistical attributes over a collection of entities, etc.
label: Social attribute

classes_PrismaticJoint.name: PrismaticJoint
comment: A sliding joint that slides along an axis, and has a limited range specified by the upper and lower limits.
label: Prismatic joint

classes_ProcessFlow.name: ProcessFlow
comment: A description that structures a Process.
label: Process flow

classes_Progression.name: Progression
comment: A situation that sattisies a description of how a process evolves over time.

classes_Protector.name: Protector
comment: A role classifying an object that protects another by preventing other entities from coming in contact with the protected object.

classes_ProximalTheory.name: ProximalTheory
comment:
An image schematic theory that describes a qualitative spatial relation indicating relative proximity, as expressed by the prepositions 'near', 'close to', 'next to', etc.

It may seem that proximity is a very simple notion, requiring no sophisticated theoretical underpinnings. However, proximity is an extremely object- and purpose-dependent relation. A store next door is in a closeness relation to a person, and so is the Sun in the sky, despite the physical distances being different by several orders of magnitude.

As such, a theory, i.e. a description of what a particular kind of closeness means and in which contexts it applies, is necessary.

Adopted from GUM-4-space (Bateman et al. 2010).

Let xL, xR be objects filling the locatum, relatum roles of this schema. Then one can infer that xL 'near to' xR.
label: Proximal theory

classes_PushingAway.name: PushingAway
comment: A task in which an Agent pushes an object in front of themselves.
label: Pushing away

classes_PushingDown.name: PushingDown
comment: A task in which an Agent pushes an object downwards.
label: Pushing down

classes_PuttingDown.name: PuttingDown
comment: A task in which an Agent puts down an object they have kinematic control over, e.g. a grasped object.

classes_QualityTransition.name: QualityTransition
comment: todo(DB): added for NEEMs (quale change), but not sure yet about it...
label: Quality transition

classes_Query.name: Query
comment: A role played by some Information Realization that carries meaning, where this meaning is a query of some sort.
label: Query

classes_QueryAnsweringTask.name: QueryAnsweringTask
comment:
An Answering task that is the reaction to some Query answering task.

In a lot of cases, such a task is also an Assertion task, e.g., in the following discourse:

"How will the weather be tomorrow?"
"It is going to rain in the morning."

However, sometimes this might be not the case, e.g., with counterquestions.
label: Query answering task

classes_QueryEngine.name: QueryEngine
comment: A Query Engine is a Software that can answer some queries.
label: Query engine

classes_Reaching.name: Reaching
comment: A task in which an Agent moves one or more of its arms towards a location or object.

classes_Retracting.name: Retracting
comment: A task in which an Agent moves its arms away from a location.

classes_Reasoner.name: Reasoner
comment:
A Reasoner is some Software that can infer new, implicit knowlegde from explicitly stated knowledge.

This definition is broad and we consider any System fitting the above description as reasoners. For example, the following can be seen as Reasoners:
* A simulation, where the explicit knowledge corresponds to the initial situation, and the implicit knowlegde corresponds to the situation that is derived from that by simulating some unfolding processes.
* A machine learning algorithm, e.g., an image classifier: The explicit knowledge is the visual content of a picture (even down to the pixel), the implicit knowledge is the derived classification.
* A logic based rule engine, where initial facts are the explicit knowledge, and derived facts are the implicit knowledge.

classes_RecipientRole.name: RecipientRole
comment: A role which classifies an agent who receives an object modified or created by an action.
label: Recipent role

classes_RedColor.name: RedColor
comment: A color region with dominant red color.
label: Red color

classes_Reification.name: Reification
comment: A description that *describes* a formal entity.

classes_RelationalDatabase.name: RelationalDatabase
comment:
A Relational Database is a Database based on the relational model of data, which organizes data into one or more tables (or "relations") of columns and rows, with a unique key identifying each row.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_database
label: Relational database

classes_RelationalQueryLanguage.name: RelationalQueryLanguage
comment: A Query Language that is designed for communication with some Relational Database.
label: Relational query language

classes_RelevantPart.name: RelevantPart
comment: Features that are relevant parts of their host, like a bump or an edge.
label: Relevant part

classes_Remembering.name: Remembering
comment:
A Mental task in which the Agent recalls a record of a previous state of affairs in the world.

The Agent must have witnessed and memorized this state of affairs in order to record it. Remembering commits itself to accuracy: the Agent attempts to reconstruct as accurate a record as it can. Note, this does not mean the Agent will communicate the recollection accurately.

The difference to Memory retrieval is that for this Task, we are concerned with knowledge about a previous world state. Memory Retrieval is more general in the sense that it also includes the retrieval of learned facts and rules.

classes_Retrospecting.name: Retrospecting
comment: A Mental task in which an Agent endeavors to construct a representation of a past state of affairs of the world it is embodied in.

Done by analogy with Prospecting. Currently mono-subcategory, but perhaps we might find more.

As an example, a kind of Abductive reasoning would fit here: reconstruction, in which the agent attempts to create a representation of a past state of affairs which the agent has not actually observed, based on traces and clues surviving to the present.

classes_RemovedObject.name: RemovedObject
comment: An object that is removed from another.
label: Removed object

classes_Replanning.name: Replanning
comment: A mental task, in which an agent reconfigures some plan that has been put together before.
label: Replanning

classes_RevoluteJoint.name: RevoluteJoint
comment: A hinge joint that rotates along an axis and has a limited range specified by the upper and lower limits.
label: Revolute joint

classes_Room.name: Room
comment: Space that can be occupied or where something can be done.

classes_RoomSurface.name: RoomSurface
comment: The surface of a room.
label: Room surface

classes_Surface.name: Surface
comment: The outside part or uppermost layer of something.

classes_Rubbing.name: Rubbing
comment: The motion of an object sliding along the surface of another, for example, to clean the surface.

classes_Theory.name: Theory
comment:
A Theory is a Description that represents a set of assumptions for describing something, usually general. Scientific, philosophical, and commonsense theories can be included here.
This class can also be used to act as 'naturalized reifications' of logical theories (of course, they will be necessarily incomplete in this case, because second-order entities are represented as first-order ones).
label: Theory

classes_SelectedObject.name: SelectedObject
comment: An object chosen as the result of some selection task.
label: Selected object

classes_Selecting.name: Selecting
comment: A Task where an Agent decides between two or more options.
label: Selecting

classes_SelectingItem.name: SelectingItem
comment: A task in which an Agent selects some object to use for a subsequent task.
label: Selecting item

classes_Serving.name: Serving
comment: The task in which the agent delivers an object to a physical agent

classes_SettingGripper.name: SettingGripper
comment: A task by which an Agent arranges one/some/all of its grippers in some configuration.
label: Setting gripper

classes_6DPose.name: 6DPose
comment: A point in three dimensional space, given as translation in a reference coordinate system, and an orientation of a coordinate system centered at that point relative to the reference coordinate system.
label: 6D pose

classes_Shaping.name: Shaping
comment: The disposition of an object (the tool) to change the shape of others.

classes_Sharpness.name: Sharpness
comment: The quality of having a thin edge or point that can cut something or make a hole into something. It is worth to note here that the social aspect of sharpness such as the quality of being clear, intelligent etc is not considered as sharpness according to this definition.

classes_Simulating.name: Simulating
comment:
A Mental task in which the Agent endeavours to create representations of a sequence of states of affairs in the world. Simulation commits itself to some degree of transition accuracy: supposing the actual state of the world was the initial state of the simulation, the world state and simulation state should evolve to some degree similarly.

Simulation does not commit itself to state accuracy: the initial state of the simulation is not constrained to be faithful to the actual state of the world in which the Agent is embodied. Counterfactual simulation ("what would happen if--?") is possible.

classes_Simulation_Reasoner.name: Simulation_Reasoner
comment: A Simulation-based Reasoner is a simulation that is used as a reasoner, where the explicit knowledge corresponds to the initial situation, and the implicit knowlegde corresponds to the situation that is derived from that by simulating some unfolding processes.
label: Simulation-based reasoner

classes_Size.name: Size
comment: The magnitude or dimension of a thing which can be measured as length, width, height, diameter, perimeter, area, volume.

classes_Slicing.name: Slicing
comment: A particular kind of cutting where the goal is to produce slices from some solid object.

classes_Sluggishness.name: Sluggishness
comment: A description of sluggish behavior.

classes_SocialState.name: SocialState
comment:
A State which describes how Agents relate to each other.

One can argue that any Social state is a Physical state, since anything the Agents may use to construct a social relationship is made of physical things. The difference is that the physical support of the social relationships is not important here, what matters instead is the nature and content of the social relations, regardless of how they are physically realized.

Note here a distinction: the Agents involved must be able to communicate. This is because while it is often assumed that an Agent has or aspires to have similar cognitive capacities to a human, This need not be the case; in particular, not all Agents need to maintain theories of mind about each other and therefore not all Agents need to communicate with each other. It is hard to see what sort of meaning Social concepts might have to such Agents, since Social concepts are all about shared constructions.

Note also that the DUL SocialAgent class is not an appropriate restriction however. SocialAgent is one that exists by agreement of PhysicalAgents. For example, a corporation or a nation are SocialAgents. An Agent with the capability to engage socially is not necessarily a DUL SocialAgent.
label: Social state

classes_SocialAgent.name: SocialAgent
comment: Any individual whose existence is granted simply by its social communicability and capability of action (through some PhysicalAgent).
label: Social agent

classes_SourceMaterialRole.name: SourceMaterialRole
comment: A role classifying a substance or object that enters a process of transformation intended to create some other object.
label: Source material role

classes_SphereShape.name: SphereShape
comment: A round solid figure with every point on its surface equidistant from its centre.
label: Sphere shape

classes_Standing.name: Standing
comment: A motion by which an Agent arranges its body in an upright configuration. Typically, it makes sense to speak of standing for bodies where some limbs are dedicated to moving the whole body while some limbs are used for manipulation of other objects.

classes_StaticFrictionAttribute.name: StaticFrictionAttribute
comment: Friction between two touching objects that do not move relative to each other.
label: Static friction attribute

classes_StatusFailure.name: StatusFailure
comment: A status indicating the failure during some workflow execution.

classes_StimulusRole.name: StimulusRole
comment: A role classifying an object that is perceived by some agent and thus triggers some reaction (e.g., a perception event).
label: Stimulus role

classes_Stirring.name: Stirring
comment: A task in which an agent dissolves small particles like sugar or salt in fluid

classes_Storage.name: Storage
comment: The disposition of an object (the container) to store other objects. Storage of an object would facilitate several objectives; such as to store objects in a safe or usual place, to prevent the substances e.g. prevention of milk going bad by storing them in a refrigrator.

classes_StructuralDesign.name: StructuralDesign
comment: A design of an object which describes its stability, strength and rigidity, and considers the way in which parts of an object are arranged.
label: Structural Design

classes_TaskInvocation.name: TaskInvocation
comment: An elementary workflow consisting in the invocation of one single task. It is used as a descriptive context inside of which factual bindings are valid between the task's arguments and other entities (such as the "local variables" of a larger workflow).
label: Task invocation

classes_SuccessDiagnosis.name: SuccessDiagnosis
comment: A diagnosis of the fullfilment of a goal that motivates the behavior of a system.
label: Success diagnosis

classes_Successfulness.name: Successfulness
comment: A description of a situation with a goal that was achieved by some system.

classes_SupportState.name: SupportState
comment: Classifies States in which an object is not able to move under gravity because of its placement relative to some other object.
label: Support state

classes_Supporter.name: Supporter
comment: A role classifying an object used to support others.

classes_SupportTheory.name: SupportTheory
comment:
An image schematic theory that describes the reified functional relation holding between two spatial objects x and y, such that x physically supports y in the presence of gravity; x and y need not be in contact. An example of such an expression is "The bowl is on the table".

This is also known as FunctionalControlExternal in GUM (Bateman et al. 2010).

Let xL, xR be objects filling the locatum, relatum roles of this schema. Then one can infer that xL isSupportedBy xR.
label: Support theory

classes_SupportedObject.name: SupportedObject
comment: An object that is supported by some supporter.
label: Supported object

classes_SymbolicReasoner.name: SymbolicReasoner
comment:
A Symbolic Reasoner, is a piece of software able to infer logical consequences from a set of asserted facts or axioms.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_reasoner
label: Symbolic reasoner

classes_Tapping.name: Tapping
comment: A motion, usually repeated several times, for example, to probe the surface of an object.

classes_Taxis.name: Taxis
comment: An innate behavioural response such as the knee-jerk reflex or the sucking reflex of human infants.

classes_Temperature.name: Temperature
comment: The heat present in an object.

classes_TemperatureRegion.name: TemperatureRegion
comment: Encodes the temperature of an object.
label: Temperature region

classes_Tempering.name: Tempering
comment: The disposition of an object (the tool) to change the temperature of others.

classes_ThinkAloud.name: ThinkAloud
comment: A task in which an Agent, while in the course of performing some other task(s), reports on their own decision processes that guide this other task(s) for the benefit of an outside observer.
label: Think-aloud

classes_ThinkAloudActionTopic.name: ThinkAloudActionTopic
comment: A topic used when an Agent states what they are doing.
label: Think aloud action topic

classes_ThinkAloudGeneralKnowledgeTopic.name: ThinkAloudGeneralKnowledgeTopic
comment: A topic used when an Agent states general knowledge they have.
label: Think aloud general knowledge topic

classes_ThinkAloudKnowledgeTopic.name: ThinkAloudKnowledgeTopic
comment: A topic used when an Agent states some item of knowledge. This knowledge can be general, or specific to the environment and task at hand.
label: Think aloud knowledge topic

classes_ThinkAloudObstructionTopic.name: ThinkAloudObstructionTopic
comment: A topic used when an Agent describes some state of affairs that prevents them from performing an action.
label: Think aloud obstruction topic

classes_ThinkAloudOpinionTopic.name: ThinkAloudOpinionTopic
comment: A topic used when an Agent expresses an opinion about the action they perform or the environment they are in.
label: Think aloud opinion topic

classes_ThinkAloudPerceptionTopic.name: ThinkAloudPerceptionTopic
comment: A topic used when an Agent describes what they currently perceive.
label: Think aloud perception topic

classes_ThinkAloudPlanTopic.name: ThinkAloudPlanTopic
comment: A topic used when an Agent describes what they intend to do. Note, this is not about describing the process through which this plan was constructed; that is covered by the MetaCognitionPlanningTopic.
label: Think aloud plan topic

classes_ThinkAloudSceneKnowledgeTopic.name: ThinkAloudSceneKnowledgeTopic
comment: A topic used when an Agent describes what they know about their environment, including knowledge of world states that they do not currently perceive.
label: Think aloud scene knowledge topic

classes_Threshold.name: Threshold
comment: A role played by a parameter which indicates some value that, when crossed, triggers some condition.

classes_Throwing.name: Throwing
comment: A task in which an Agent imparts momentum to an object before releasing it so that it flies for some distance unsupported.

classes_TimeRole.name: TimeRole
comment: A role filled by a description of the location in time and/or duration of an event or object.
label: Time role

classes_Transporting.name: Transporting
comment: A task by which an Agent carries an item from a source to a destination location.

classes_Triplestore.name: Triplestore
comment: A Triplestore or RDF store is a purpose-built database for the storage and retrieval of triples through semantic queries.
label: Triplestore

classes_Turning.name: Turning
comment: A motion by which an agent changes which way their body faces.

classes_UnavailableSoftware.name: UnavailableSoftware
comment: A description of a situation where some software dependency is not available.
label: Unavailable software

classes_VideoData.name: VideoData
comment: An information object containing data for audio-visual modalities.
label: Video data

classes_3DPosition.name: 3DPosition
comment: A point in three dimensional space, given as translation.
label: 3D position

object_properties_affects.name: affects
comment: Simple relationship between two actions to express that a variation in the course or outcome of the subject (the affector) would have resulted in a variation in the object (the affectee), e.g., a planning task that sets parameters such as goal position affects the subsequently executed pick-and-place task that uses that parameter.
label: affects

object_properties_precedes.name: precedes
comment:
A relation between entities, expressing a 'sequence' schema. 
E.g. 'year 1999 precedes 2000', 'deciding what coffee to use' precedes 'preparing coffee', 'World War II follows World War I', 'in the Milan to Rome autoroute, Bologna precedes Florence', etc.
It can then be used between tasks, processes, time intervals, spatially locate objects, situations, etc. 
Subproperties can be defined in order to distinguish the different uses.
label: precedes

object_properties_isAffectedBy.name: isAffectedBy
comment: Simple relationship between two actions to express that a variation in the course or outcome of the object (the affector) would have resulted in a variation in the subject (the affectee), e.g., a planning task that sets parameters such as goal position affects the subsequently executed pick-and-place task that uses that parameter.
label: is affected by

object_properties_affordanceDefines.name: affordanceDefines
comment: A relation between an Affordance and a Concept (often an EventType).
label: affordance defines

object_properties_defines.name: defines
comment: A relation between a Description and a Concept, e.g. a Workflow for a governmental Organization defines the Role 'officer', or 'the Italian Traffic Law defines the role Vehicle'.
label: defines

object_properties_isDefinedInAffordance.name: isDefinedInAffordance
comment: A relation between a Concept and an Affordance.
label: is defined in affordance

object_properties_affordanceDefinesTask.name: affordanceDefinesTask
comment: A relation between an Affordance and a Task
label: affordance defines task

object_properties_definesTask.name: definesTask
comment: A relation between a description and a task, e.g. the recipe for a cake defines the task 'boil'.
label: defines task

object_properties_isTaskDefinedInAfforda.name: isTaskDefinedInAffordance
comment: A relation between a Task and an Affordance, such that the task is defined in terms of using the affordance.
label: is task defined in affordance

object_properties_affordsBearer.name: affordsBearer
comment: Relates a disposition to the bearer role defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: affords bearer

object_properties_affordsConcept.name: affordsConcept
comment: A relation between a disposition and a concept defined in the affordance that describes the disposition.
label: affords concept

object_properties_isBearerAffordedBy.name: isBearerAffordedBy
comment: Relates a disposition to the bearer role defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: is bearer afforded by

object_properties_isDescribedBy.name: isDescribedBy
comment:
The relation between an Entity and a Description: a Description gives a unity to a Collection of parts (the components), or constituents, by assigning a Role to each of them in the context of a whole Object (the system).
A same Entity can be given different descriptions, for example, an old cradle can be given a unifying Description based on the original aesthetic design, the functionality it was built for, or a new aesthetic functionality in which it can be used as a flower pot.
label: is described by

object_properties_definesBearer.name: definesBearer
comment: Relates an affordance which is a relation between a bearer and a trigger, to the role of the bearer when the affordance is manifested.
label: defines bearer

object_properties_associatedWith.name: associatedWith
comment:
A catch-all object property, useful for alignment and querying purposes.
It is declared as both transitive and symmetric, in order to reason an a maximal closure of associations between individuals.
label: associated with

object_properties_isConceptAffordedBy.name: isConceptAffordedBy
comment: A relation between a disposition and a concept defined in the affordance that describes the disposition.
label: is concept afforded by

object_properties_affordsPerformer.name: affordsPerformer
comment: Relates a disposition to the performer role defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: affords performer

object_properties_definesPerformer.name: definesPerformer
comment: Relates an affordance which is a relation between a bearer and a trigger, to the role of the performer when the affordance is manifested.
label: defines performer

object_properties_affordsSetpoint.name: affordsSetpoint
comment: Relates a disposition to the setpoint parameter defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: affords setpoint

object_properties_isSetpointAffordedBy.name: isSetpointAffordedBy
comment: Relates a disposition to the setpoint parameter defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: is setpoint afforded by

object_properties_definesSetpoint.name: definesSetpoint
comment: Defines the dedicated goal region of a description.
label: defines setpoint

object_properties_affordsTask.name: affordsTask
comment: Relates a disposition to the task defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: affords task

object_properties_isTaskAffordedBy.name: isTaskAffordedBy
comment: Relates a disposition to the task defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: is task afforded by

object_properties_affordsTrigger.name: affordsTrigger
comment: Relates a disposition to the trigger role defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: affords trigger

object_properties_isTriggerAffordedBy.name: isTriggerAffordedBy
comment: Relates a disposition to the trigger role defined by the affordance describing the disposition.
label: is trigger afforded by

object_properties_definesTrigger.name: definesTrigger
comment: Relates an affordance which is a relation between a bearer and a trigger, to the role of the trigger when the affordance is manifested.
label: defines trigger

object_properties_after.name: after
comment: A relation between entities, expressing a 'sequence' schema where one of the entities strictly ends before the other one.

object_properties_follows.name: follows
comment:
A relation between entities, expressing a 'sequence' schema. 
E.g. 'year 2000 follows 1999', 'preparing coffee' follows 'deciding what coffee to use', 'II World War follows I World War', etc. 
It can be used between tasks, processes or time intervals, and subproperties would fit best in order to distinguish the different uses.
label: follows

object_properties_before.name: before
comment: A relation between entities, expressing a 'sequence' schema where one of the entities strictly ends before the other one.

object_properties_relatesToAnotherRole.name: relatesToAnotherRole
comment: Simple top-level property for relations between two roles.
label: relates to another role

object_properties_hasAnswer.name: hasAnswer
comment: The relation between a message and its answer.
label: has answer

object_properties_isReactionTo.name: isReactionTo
comment:
Simple relationship between two actions to express that the subject (the reaction) would not have occured if it were not for the object (the cause), e.g., a Communication Action classified as an Answering Task is a reaction to another Communication Task classified as a Query Task and would not have occured without the other. An example without Agents involved would be some domino stone would not have toppled without the first one toppling.

When Agents are involved, the relation might be seen as an abstraction of the execution of some plan that arises from changing the agents goal that is due to perceiving the cause. However, currently it is unclear how to model such a pattern and therefore not included in SOMA.

This relation is seen as transitive.
label: is reaction to

object_properties_causesTransition.name: causesTransition
comment: A Transition between two Situations is always the result of some Event, and the causesTransition relation should be used to record the causal relation from the Event to the Transition.
label: causes transition

object_properties_isCausedByEvent.name: isCausedByEvent
comment: A relation recording that a Transition is the result of some Event.
label: is caused by event

object_properties_coOccurs.name: coOccurs
comment:
A schematic relation between any events that also implies that one event is temporally contained in the other.

Sub-properties are used to distinct between different cases of event endpoint relations that hold for different types of co-occurance.
label: co occurs

object_properties_overlaps.name: overlaps
comment:
A schematic relation between any entities, e.g. 'the chest region overlaps with the abdomen region', 'my spoken words overlap with hers', 'the time of my leave overlaps with the time of your arrival', 'fibromyalgia overlaps with other conditions'.
Subproperties and restrictions can be used to specialize overlaps for objects, events, time intervals, etc.
label: overlaps

object_properties_contains.name: contains
comment: A schematic relation asserting containment, understood in a very broad sense, by one Entity of another. The relation is defined with domain and range of maximum generality, as it is possible to construe containment to apply between Events, between Objects, between Qualities and so on. Care should be taken when using it that the construal of containment makes sense and is useful. If a clearer relation expresses the connection between two Entities, use that relation instead. For example, rather than saying an Event contains an Object, it is probably better to say the Event has that Object as a participant. More specific versions of this relation exist, e.g. containsEvent, so it is likely that there will be few situations where it should be used itself. However, by acting as a superproperty to several relations, it captures a core similarity between these and enables taxonomy-based similarity metrics.

object_properties_isContainedIn.name: isContainedIn
comment: The inverse of the contains relation. See the contains relation for details.
label: is contained in

object_properties_containsEvent.name: containsEvent
comment: `A contains event B` means that A strictly starts before, and ends after B, i.e. B is wholly contained in A.
label: contains event

object_properties_during.name: during
comment: `A during B` means that B strictly starts before, and ends after A, i.e. A is wholly contained in B.

object_properties_containsObject.name: containsObject
comment: A spatial relation holding between a container, and objects it contains.
label: contains object

object_properties_isLocationOf.name: isLocationOf
comment:
A generic, relative localization, holding between any entities. E.g. 'Rome is the seat of the Pope', 'the liver is the location of the tumor'.
For 'absolute' locations, see SpaceRegion
label: is location of

object_properties_isInsideOf.name: isInsideOf
comment: A spatial relation holding between an object (the container), and objects it contains.
label: is inside of

object_properties_coversObject.name: coversObject
comment: A relationship from an object (the coverer) that blocks access to another or its interior (the coveree).

object_properties_interactsWith.name: interactsWith
comment: A relation between objects that interact with each other.
label: interacts with

object_properties_isCoveredByObject.name: isCoveredByObject
comment: A relation from an object (the coveree) which is itself, or has its interior, prevented from being accessed from outside by a coverer.

object_properties_definesRole.name: definesRole
comment: A relation between a description and a role, e.g. the recipe for a cake defines the role 'ingredient'.
label: defines role

object_properties_isBearerDefinedIn.name: isBearerDefinedIn
comment: Relates an affordance which is a relation between a bearer and a trigger, to the role of the bearer when the affordance is manifested.
label: is bearer defined in

object_properties_isEventTypeDefinedIn.name: isEventTypeDefinedIn
comment:
A relation between an event type and a description, e.g. an event that is described by the Affordance of an object to be cut with a knife.

The distinction to 'is task defined in' is necessary to let Dispositions and Affordances not only describe which tasks might be afforded by objects, but also whihc processes (where there is no agent). For example, the fall of a knife from a shelf slicing a loaf of bread on impact is , in the absence of an executing agent, not a task but merely a process, the possibility of which is nevertheless described by the dispositions of the knife and the loaf.
label: is event type defined in

object_properties_definesInput.name: definesInput

object_properties_definesParticipant.name: definesParticipant
comment:
A Description definesParticipant a Concept to classify participants in Events associated to that Description.

The prototypical example is a Task, which is a concept to classify Actions (a form of Event). A Task may define several Roles, with which to classify participants in the event of that Task's execution.

object_properties_definesOutput.name: definesOutput

object_properties_definesParameter.name: definesParameter
comment: A relation between a description and a parameter.
label: defines parameter

object_properties_isParameterDefinedIn.name: isParameterDefinedIn
comment: A relation between a description and a parameter.
label: is parameter defined in

object_properties_isPerformerDefinedIn.name: isPerformerDefinedIn
comment: Relates an affordance which is a relation between a bearer and a trigger, to the role of the performer when the affordance is manifested.
label: is performer defined in

object_properties_definesProcess.name: definesProcess
comment: A relation between a description and a process type.
label: defines process

object_properties_isProcessDefinedIn.name: isProcessDefinedIn
comment: A relation between a process type and a description that defines it.
label: is process defined in

object_properties_isSetpointDefinedIn.name: isSetpointDefinedIn
comment: Defines the dedicated goal region of a description.
label: is setpoint defined in

object_properties_isTriggerDefinedIn.name: isTriggerDefinedIn
comment: Relates an affordance which is a relation between a bearer and a trigger, to the role of the trigger when the affordance is manifested.
label: is trigger defined in

object_properties_derivedFrom.name: derivedFrom
comment: The (transitive) relation between an information object and another which it has been derived from.
label: derived from

object_properties_isSourceFor.name: isSourceFor
comment: The (transitive) relation between an information object and another which was derived from the former.
label: is source for

object_properties_describesQuality.name: describesQuality
comment: Relates a description to a quality that it describes.
label: describes quality

object_properties_describes.name: describes
comment:
The relation between a Description and an Entity : a Description gives a unity to a Collection of parts (the components), or constituents, by assigning a Role to each of them in the context of a whole Object (the system).
A same Entity can be given different descriptions, for example, an old cradle can be given a unifying Description based on the original aesthetic design, the functionality it was built for, or a new aesthetic functionality in which it can be used as a flower pot.
label: describes

object_properties_isQualityDescribedBy.name: isQualityDescribedBy
