comment: Relates a description to a quality it describes.
label: is quality described by

object_properties_directlyCauses.name: directlyCauses
comment: Non-transitive version of "causes".
label: directly causes

object_properties_isDirectReactionTo.name: isDirectReactionTo
comment: Non-transitive version of "is reaction to".
label: is direct reaction to

object_properties_hasTerminalScene.name: hasTerminalScene
comment: A relation between StateTransitions and Scenes, which identifies the scene the transition is expected to end at.
label: has terminal scene

object_properties_includesEvent.name: includesEvent
comment: A relation between situations and events, e.g. 'this morning I've prepared my coffee and had my fingers burnt' (i.e.: the preparation of my coffee this morning included a burning of my fingers).
label: includes event

object_properties_directlyDerivedFrom.name: directlyDerivedFrom
comment: The relation between an information object and another which it has been derived from.
label: directly derived from

object_properties_isDirectSourceFor.name: isDirectSourceFor
comment: The (transitive) relation between an information object and another which was derived from the former.
label: is direct source for

object_properties_encapsulates.name: encapsulates
comment: The relation between an Ordered element' and an 'Entity' it contains.
label: encapsulates

object_properties_encodes.name: encodes
comment: The relation between two Information Objects that have the same meaning, but are formatted differently. E.g., a text written in UTF-8 encodes a text in a natural writing system (letters) and vice versa.

object_properties_finishedBy.name: finishedBy
comment: `A finishes B` means that A ends exactly where B ends, and that B strictly starts before A.  As in "I finish my day by taking a shower".
label: finished by

object_properties_finishes.name: finishes
comment: `A finishes B` means that A ends exactly where B ends, and that B strictly starts before A.  As in "I finish my day by taking a shower".

object_properties_firstMember.name: firstMember
comment: A relation between a collection and a member of it that is least according to some ordering. This ordering can be arbitrary, i.e. the order in which Entities are recorded in the Collection.
label: first member

object_properties_hasMember.name: hasMember
comment: A relation between collections and entities, e.g. 'my collection of saxophones includes an old Adolphe Sax original alto' (i.e. my collection has member an Adolphe Sax alto).
label: has member

object_properties_givesMeaningTo.name: givesMeaningTo
comment: The relation between a System and Information Object that is given meaning to by said system, e.g., a Language might give meaning to some word, sentence, text, etc., but without the knowledge of said System (Language), the text will not make sense to a reader.
label: gives meaning to

object_properties_isGivenMeaningBy.name: isGivenMeaningBy
comment: The relation between an Information Object and a System that gives meaning to said object, e.g., a word, sentence, text, etc. might be given meaning by a Language and without the knowledge of said System (Language), the text will not make sense to a reader.
label: is given meaning by

object_properties_hasAction.name: hasAction
comment: A relation from an Action to a component Action.
label: has action

object_properties_hasConstituent.name: hasConstituent
comment:
'Constituency' depends on some layering of  the world described by the ontology. For example, scientific granularities (e.g. body-organ-tissue-cell) or ontological 'strata' (e.g. social-mental-biological-physical) are  typical layerings. 
Intuitively, a constituent is a part belonging to a lower layer. Since layering is actually a partition of the world described by the ontology, constituents are not properly classified as parts, although this kinship can be intuitive for common sense.
A desirable advantage of this distinction is that we are able to talk e.g. of physical constituents of non-physical objects (e.g. systems), while this is not possible in terms of parts.
Example of are the persons constituting a social system, the molecules constituting a person, the atoms constituting a river, etc. 
In all these examples, we notice a typical discontinuity between the constituted and the constituent object: e.g. a social system is conceptualized at a different layer from the persons that constitute it, a person is conceptualized at a different layer from the molecules that constitute them, and a river is conceptualized at a different layer from the atoms that constitute it.
label: has constituent

object_properties_hasAlterationResult.name: hasAlterationResult
comment: Relates an action that alters an object to the region that the alteration reached during the action.
label: has alteration result

object_properties_hasRegion.name: hasRegion
comment: A relation between entities and regions, e.g. 'the number of wheels of that truck is 12', 'the time of the experiment is August 9th, 2004', 'the whale has been localized at 34 degrees E, 20 degrees S'.
label: has region

object_properties_isAlterationResultOf.name: isAlterationResultOf
comment: Relates an action that alters an object to the region that the alteration reached during the action.
label: is alteration result of

object_properties_hasBinding.name: hasBinding
comment: Asserts that in a context described by Description, a Binding relation holds.
label: has binding

object_properties_hasPart.name: hasPart
comment:
A schematic relation between any entities, e.g. 'the human body has a brain as part', '20th century contains year 1923', 'World War II includes the Pearl Harbour event'.

Parthood should assume the basic properties of mereology: transitivity, antisymmetry, and reflexivity (propert Parthood of course misses reflexivity). 
However, antisymmetry is not supported in OWL2 explicitly, therefore DUL has to adopt one of two patterns:
1) dropping asymmetry axioms, while granting reflexivity: this means that symmetry is not enforced, but permitted for the case of reflexivity. Of course, in this way we cannot prevent symmetric usages of hasPart;
2) dropping the reflexivity axiom, and enforce asymmetry: in this case, we would prevent all symmetric usages, but we loose the possibility of enforcing reflexivity, which is commonsensical in parthood.
In DUL, we adopt pattern #1 for partOf, and pattern #2 for properPartOf, which seems a good approximation: due to the lack of inheritance of property characteristics, each asymmetric hasPropertPart assertion would also be a reflexive hasPart assertion (reflexive reduction design pattern).

Subproperties and restrictions can be used to specialize hasPart for objects, events, etc.
label: has part

object_properties_hasBindingFiller.name: hasBindingFiller
comment:
Indicates that an Entity is described by a Binding, in that it is associated with the Role/Parameter that the Binding binds it to. The Binding is only valid in some descriptive context such as a Workflow or Narrative.

Note, the filler can be a Role/Parameter as well, and there are two distinct interpretations, depending on whether the Binding is a RoleRoleBinding or a RoleFillerBinding. See the comments on Binding for more details.

Only RoleFillerBindings can have general Entities as fillers. RoleRoleBindings can only connect to Roles or Parameters via this property.
label: has binding filler

object_properties_hasBindingRole.name: hasBindingRole
comment: Indicates that a Role/Parameter is going to be associated to some filler, or other Role/Parameter, by a Binding. The Binding is only valid in some descriptive context such as a Narrative or Workflow.
label: has binding role

object_properties_hasChildLink.name: hasChildLink
comment: Relates a joint to the link it connects which is closer to the end of the kinematic chain.
label: has child link

object_properties_isChildLinkOf.name: isChildLinkOf
comment: Relates a joint to the link it connects which is closer to the end of the kinematic chain.
label: is child link of

object_properties_hasColor.name: hasColor
comment: Relates an object to its color quality.
label: has color

object_properties_hasQuality.name: hasQuality
comment: A relation between entities and qualities, e.g. 'Dmitri's skin is yellowish'.
label: has quality

object_properties_isColorOf.name: isColorOf
comment: Relates a color quality to the object the color belongs to.
label: is color of

object_properties_hasDisposition.name: hasDisposition
comment: Associates an object to one of its dispositions.
label: has disposition

object_properties_isDispositionOf.name: isDispositionOf
comment: Associates a disposition quality to the object holding it.
label: is disposition of

object_properties_hasEndLink.name: hasEndLink
comment: Relates an object to kinematic components at the end of the kinematic chain.
label: has end link

object_properties_hasLink.name: hasLink
comment: Relates an object to its kinematic components.
label: has link

object_properties_isEndLinkOf.name: isEndLinkOf
comment: Relates an object to kinematic components at the end of the kinematic chain.
label: is end link of

object_properties_hasExecutionState.name: hasExecutionState
comment: A relation from an Action to its execution state.
label: has execution state

object_properties_hasFeature.name: hasFeature
comment: Associates a physical object to one of its features.
label: has feature

object_properties_isFeatureOf.name: isFeatureOf
comment: Associates a feature to the physical object it belongs to.
label: is feature of

object_properties_hasFirstStep.name: hasFirstStep
comment: A relation from a Workflow to its first Task.
label: has first step

object_properties_hasStep.name: hasStep
comment: A relation between a Workflow and a Task it contains.
label: has step

object_properties_isFirstStepOf.name: isFirstStepOf
comment: A relation stating that some task is the first one in a workflow.
label: is first step of

object_properties_hasFrictionAttribute.name: hasFrictionAttribute
comment: A relation between physical objects and their friction attribute.
label: has friction attribute

object_properties_hasGoal.name: hasGoal
comment: A relation from an Entity to a Goal it pursues. Agents can pursue Goals, and Tasks are also construed as pursuing Goals.
label: has goal

object_properties_hasInitialScene.name: hasInitialScene
comment: A relation between StateTransitions and Scenes, which identifies the scene the transition starts from.
label: has initial scene

object_properties_hasInitialState.name: hasInitialState
comment: A relation which connects a Transition to the Situation it starts from.
label: has initial state

object_properties_isInitialSceneOf.name: isInitialSceneOf
comment: A relation between StateTransitions and Scenes, which identifies the scene the transition starts from.
label: is initial scene of

object_properties_hasInitialSituation.name: hasInitialSituation
comment: A relation between SituationTransitions and Situations, which identifies the Situation the transition starts from.
label: has initial situation

object_properties_isInitialSituationOf.name: isInitialSituationOf
comment: A relation between SituationTransitions and Situations, which identifies the Situation the transition starts from.
label: is initial situation of

object_properties_includesSituation.name: includesSituation
comment: A relation recording that a Situation has a (sub) Situation as participant in some role.
label: includes situation

object_properties_isInitialStateOf.name: isInitialStateOf
comment: A relation recording that a Situation was where a Transition began.
label: is initial state of

object_properties_hasInputParameter.name: hasInputParameter
comment: A relation between a Task and one of its input parameters.

A relation from an EventType (typically, a Task) and a parameter describing some state of affairs before the event classified by the EventType takes place, and which contributes towards that event happening.
label: has input parameter

object_properties_hasParameter.name: hasParameter
comment: A Concept can have a Parameter that constrains the attributes that a classified Entity can have in a certain Situation, e.g. a 4WheelDriver Role definedIn the ItalianTrafficLaw has a MinimumAge parameter on the Amount 16.
label: has parameter

object_properties_isInputParameterFor.name: isInputParameterFor
comment: A relation between a Task and one of its input parameters.
A relation from a Parameter to an EventType (typically, a Task). The parameter describes some state of affairs that precedes and will contribute to the event classified by the EventType.
label: is input parameter for

object_properties_hasJointLimit.name: hasJointLimit
comment: Relates a joint to its physical limits.
label: has joint limit

object_properties_isJointLimitOf.name: isJointLimitOf
comment: Relates a joint to its physical limits.
label: is joint limit of

object_properties_hasJointState.name: hasJointState
comment: Relates a joint to its state.
label: has joint state

object_properties_isJointStateOf.name: isJointStateOf
comment: Relates a joint to its state.
label: is joint state of

object_properties_hasComponent.name: hasComponent
comment: The hasProperPart relation without transitivity, holding between an Object (the system) and another (the component), and assuming a Design that structures the Object.
label: ha componente
has component

object_properties_isLinkOf.name: isLinkOf
comment: Relates an object to its kinematic components.
label: is link of

object_properties_hasLocalization.name: hasLocalization
comment: Relates an object to its localization quality.

object_properties_isLocalizationOf.name: isLocalizationOf
comment: Relates a localization quality to the object the localization belongs to.
label: is localization of

object_properties_hasMassAttribute.name: hasMassAttribute
comment: A relation between physical objects and their mass.

object_properties_isMassAttributeOf.name: isMassAttributeOf
comment: A relation between physical objects and their mass.
label: is mass attribute of

object_properties_hasNetForce.name: hasNetForce

label: has net force

object_properties_isNetForceOf.name: isNetForceOf
comment: A relation between a physical object and the total force acting on it.
label: is net force of

object_properties_hasNextStep.name: hasNextStep
comment: An ordering relation between tasks in a workflow, saying that a task is followed by another.
label: has next step

object_properties_directlyPrecedes.name: directlyPrecedes
comment: The intransitive precedes relation. For example, Monday directly precedes Tuesday. Directness of precedence depends on the designer conceptualization.
label: directly precedes

object_properties_hasPreviousStep.name: hasPreviousStep
comment: An ordering relation between tasks in some workflow, stating that a task is preceded by another.
label: has previous step

object_properties_hasOutputParameter.name: hasOutputParameter
comment: A relation between a Task and one of its output parameters.
A relation from an EventType (typically a Task) to a Parameter describing an outcome of the event classified by the EventType.
label: has output parameter

object_properties_isOutputParameterFor.name: isOutputParameterFor
comment: A relation between a Task and one of its output parameters.
A relation from a Parameter to an EventType (typically, a Task). The parameter describes an outcome of the event classified by the EventType.
label: is output parameter for

object_properties_hasParentLink.name: hasParentLink
comment: Relates a joint to the link it connects which is closer to the root of the kinematic chain.
label: has parent link

object_properties_isParentLinkOf.name: isParentLinkOf
comment: Relates a joint to the link it connects which is closer to the root of the kinematic chain.
label: is parent link of

object_properties_hasPhase.name: hasPhase
comment: A relation used to describe the structure of an Action or Process in terms of phases, i.e. subprocesses and states that occur during its unfolding.
label: has phase

object_properties_hasPhysicalComponent.name: hasPhysicalComponent
comment: A relation used to describe the structure of a PhysicalObject in terms of physical components, i.e. what other PhysicalObjects are components of it.
label: has physical component

object_properties_hasPredecessor.name: hasPredecessor
comment: Indicates that a Task is the predecessor in a Succedence Relation; that is, this is the task to execute first.
label: has predecessor

object_properties_isPreferenceOf.name: isPreferenceOf
comment: Relates a preference quality to the agent the preference belongs to.
label: is preference of

object_properties_directlyFollows.name: directlyFollows
comment: The intransitive follows relation. For example, Wednesday directly precedes Thursday. Directness of precedence depends on the designer conceptualization.
label: directly follows

object_properties_hasProcessType.name: hasProcessType
comment: A relation between roles and process types, e.g. a catalysator is needed to trigger some chemical reaction.
label: has process type

object_properties_isRelatedToConcept.name: isRelatedToConcept
comment: Any relation between concepts, e.g. superordinated, conceptual parthood, having a parameter, having a task, superordination, etc.
label: is related to concept

object_properties_isProcessTypeOf.name: isProcessTypeOf
comment: A relation between roles and process types, e.g. a catalysator is needed to trigger some chemical reaction.
label: is process type of

object_properties_hasQuale.name: hasQuale
comment: Relates a quality to its "value", called quale, which is an atomic quality region.
label: has quale

object_properties_isQualeOf.name: isQualeOf
comment: Relates a quality to its "value", called quale, which is an atomic quality region.
label: is quale of

object_properties_hasRootLink.name: hasRootLink
comment: Relates an object to kinematic components at the root of the kinematic chain.
label: has root link

object_properties_isRootLinkOf.name: isRootLinkOf
comment: Relates an object to kinematic components at the root of the kinematic chain.
label: is root link of

object_properties_hasShape.name: hasShape
comment: Relates an object to its shape quality.
label: has shape

object_properties_isShapeOf.name: isShapeOf
comment: Relates a shape quality to the object the shape belongs to.
label: is shape of

object_properties_hasShapeRegion.name: hasShapeRegion
comment: A relation between physical objects and their shape attribute.
label: has shape region

object_properties_isShapeRegionOf.name: isShapeRegionOf
comment: Relates a shape to a physical object that has it.
label: is shape region of

object_properties_hasSoftwareAgent.name: hasSoftwareAgent
comment: A relation from an Event and the SoftwareAgent responsible for making that Event happen.
label: has software agent

object_properties_involvesAgent.name: involvesAgent
comment: Agent participation.
label: involves agent

object_properties_hasSpaceRegion.name: hasSpaceRegion
comment: Relates an entity to a space region.
label: has space region

object_properties_isSpaceRegionFor.name: isSpaceRegionFor
comment: Relates a space region to an entity.
label: is space region for

object_properties_hasStateType.name: hasStateType
comment: A relation between roles and state types, e.g. 'the chair is the supporter of the person sitting on it'.
label: has state type

object_properties_isStateTypeOf.name: isStateTypeOf
comment: A relation between roles and state types, e.g. 'the chair is the supporter of the person sitting on it'.
label: is state type of

object_properties_hasStatus.name: hasStatus
comment: A relation from an Entity to a Quality that is indicative of the Entity's state, e.g. if it is a device, its state of operation.
label: has status

object_properties_isStepOf.name: isStepOf
comment: A relation stating that a task is a step in a workflow.
label: is step of

object_properties_hasSuccedence.name: hasSuccedence
comment: A relation between a Workflow and a Succedence that appears in it.

object_properties_hasSuccessor.name: hasSuccessor
comment: Indicates that a Task is the successor in a Succedence Relation: that is, it is the Task to execute last.
label: has successor

object_properties_hasTask.name: hasTask
comment: A relation between roles and tasks, e.g. 'students have the duty of giving exams' (i.e. the Role 'student' hasTask the Task 'giving exams').
label: has task

object_properties_hasTerminalState.name: hasTerminalState
comment: A relation from a Transition to the Situation it ends in.

object_properties_isTerminalSceneOf.name: isTerminalSceneOf
comment: A relation between StateTransitions and Scenes, which identifies the scene the transition is expected to end at.
label: is terminal scene of

object_properties_hasTerminalSituation.name: hasTerminalSituation
comment: A relation between SituationTransitions and Situations, which identifies the Situation the transition ends at.
label: has terminal situation

object_properties_isTerminalSituationOf.name: isTerminalSituationOf
comment: A relation between SituationTransitions and Situations, which identifies the Situation the transition ends at.
label: is terminal situation of

object_properties_isTerminalStateOf.name: isTerminalStateOf
comment: A relation recording that a Situation was where a Transition ended.
label: is terminal state of

object_properties_includesConcept.name: includesConcept
comment: A relation recording that a Situation has a Concept as participant in some sort of role.
label: includes concept

object_properties_includesObject.name: includesObject
comment: A relation between situations and objects, e.g. 'this morning I've prepared my coffee and had my fingers burnt' (i.e.: the preparation of my coffee this morning included me).
label: includes object

object_properties_isConceptIncludedIn.name: isConceptIncludedIn
comment: A relation recording that a Concept participates in a Situation in some way.
label: is concept included in

object_properties_includesRecord.name: includesRecord
comment: A relationship indicating that an Event has been recorded by an InformationObject

object_properties_isReferenceOf.name: isReferenceOf
comment:
A relation between information objects and any Entity (including information objects). It can be used to talk about e.g. entities are references of proper nouns: the proper noun 'Leonardo da Vinci' isAbout the Person Leonardo da Vinci; as well as to talk about sets of entities that can be described by a common noun: the common noun 'person' isAbout the set of all persons in a domain of discourse, which can be represented in DOLCE-Ultralite as an individual of the class: Collection .
The isReferenceOf relation is irreflexive, differently from its inverse isAbout.
label: is reference of

object_properties_isRecordIncludedBy.name: isRecordIncludedBy
comment: A relationship indicating that an InformationObject is a recording of an Event.

object_properties_isSettingFor.name: isSettingFor
comment: A relation between situations and entities, e.g. 'this morning I've prepared my coffee with a new fantastic Arabica', i.e.: the preparation of my coffee this morning is the setting for (an amount of) a new fantastic Arabica.
label: is setting for

object_properties_isSituationIncludedIn.name: isSituationIncludedIn
comment: A relation recording that a Situation participates in another in some role, or can be considered as a subsituation of the other.
label: is situation included in

object_properties_involvesArtifact.name: involvesArtifact
comment: Artifact participation.
label: involves artifact

object_properties_hasParticipant.name: hasParticipant
comment: A relation between an object and a process, e.g. 'John took part in the discussion', 'a large mass of snow fell during the avalanche', or 'a cook, some sugar, flour, etc. are all present in the cooking of a cake'.
label: has participant

object_properties_isArtifactInvolvedIn.name: isArtifactInvolvedIn
comment: Artifact participation.
label: is artifact involved in

object_properties_involvesEffector.name: involvesEffector
comment: Effector participation.
label: involves effector

object_properties_isEffectorInvolvedIn.name: isEffectorInvolvedIn
comment: Effector participation.
label: is effector involved in

object_properties_involvesPlace.name: involvesPlace
comment: A relation recording that an Event makes some use of a PhysicalPlace. Typically this place is where the Event is located.
label: involves place

object_properties_isPlaceInvolvedIn.name: isPlaceInvolvedIn
comment: A relation recording that a PhysicalPlace is involved in some Event; typically, this is where the Event is located.
label: is place involved in

object_properties_isRegionFor.name: isRegionFor
comment: A relation between entities and regions, e.g. 'the color of my car is red'.
label: is region for

object_properties_isAnsweredBy.name: isAnsweredBy
comment: A relation from a Query to an Agent who answers it.
label: is answered by

object_properties_isParticipantIn.name: isParticipantIn
comment: A relation between an object and a process, e.g. 'John took part in the discussion', 'a large mass of snow fell during the avalanche', or 'a cook, some sugar, flour, etc. are all present in the cooking of a cake'.
label: is participant in

object_properties_isAskedBy.name: isAskedBy
comment: A relation from a Query to the Agent who asks it.
label: is asked by

object_properties_isRoleDefinedIn.name: isRoleDefinedIn
comment: A relation between a description and a role, e.g. the role 'Ingredient' is defined in the recipe for a cake.
label: is role defined in

object_properties_isConstituentOf.name: isConstituentOf
comment:
'Constituency' depends on some layering of  the world described by the ontology. For example, scientific granularities (e.g. body-organ-tissue-cell) or ontological 'strata' (e.g. social-mental-biological-physical) are  typical layerings. 
Intuitively, a constituent is a part belonging to a lower layer. Since layering is actually a partition of the world described by the ontology, constituents are not properly classified as parts, although this kinship can be intuitive for common sense.
A desirable advantage of this distinction is that we are able to talk e.g. of physical constituents of non-physical objects (e.g. systems), while this is not possible in terms of parts.
Example of are the persons constituting a social system, the molecules constituting a person, the atoms constituting a river, etc. 
In all these examples, we notice a typical discontinuity between the constituted and the constituent object: e.g. a social system is conceptualized at a different layer from the persons that constitute it, a person is conceptualized at a different layer from the molecules that constitute them, and a river is conceptualized at a different layer from the atoms that constitute it.
label: is constituent of

object_properties_isQualityOf.name: isQualityOf
comment: A relation between entities and qualities, e.g. 'Dmitri's skin is yellowish'.
label: is quality of

object_properties_isCreatedOutputOf.name: isCreatedOutputOf
comment: A relation between a created output role and its Task. The difference to isOutputRoleOf is that the latter is also applicable, e.g., for Deciding between objects, where the selected object is not created, but still an outcome of that task.
label: is created output of

object_properties_isOutputRoleOf.name: isOutputRoleOf
comment: A relation between an output roles and its Task.
label: is output role of

object_properties_isTaskOfCreatedRole.name: isTaskOfCreatedRole
comment: A relation between a Task and one of its output roles. The difference to IsTaskOfOutputRole is that the latter is also applicable, e.g., for Deciding between objects, where the selected object is not created, but still an outcome of that task.
label: is task of created role

object_properties_isDefinedIn.name: isDefinedIn
comment: A relation between a Description and a Concept, e.g. a Workflow for a governmental Organization defines the Role 'officer', or 'the Italian Traffic Law defines the role Vehicle'.
label: is defined in

object_properties_isDepositOf.name: isDepositOf
comment: A spatial relation holding between an object (the deposit), and objects that are located ontop of it.
label: is deposit of

object_properties_isOntopOf.name: isOntopOf
comment: A spatial relation holding between an object (the deposit), and objects that are located ontop of it.
label: is ontop of

object_properties_isDesignFor.name: isDesignFor
comment: A special relation between a Design and an Object, to indicate that the Design describes a way to construct the Object.
label: is design for

object_properties_isDesignedBy.name: isDesignedBy
comment: A special relation between a Design and an Object, to indicate that the Object is described by the Design.
label: is designed by

object_properties_isRealizedBy.name: isRealizedBy
comment: A relation between an information realization and an information object, e.g. the paper copy of the Italian Constitution realizes the text of the Constitution.
label: is realized by

object_properties_hasRole.name: hasRole
comment: A relation between an object and a role, e.g. the person 'John' has role 'student'.
label: has role

object_properties_isInputRoleOf.name: isInputRoleOf
comment: A relation between an input roles and its Task.
label: is input role of

object_properties_isRoleOf.name: isRoleOf
comment: A relation between an object and a role, e.g. 'student' is the role of 'John'.
label: is role of

object_properties_realizes.name: realizes
comment: A relation between an information realization and an information object, e.g. the paper copy of the Italian Constitution realizes the text of the Constitution.
label: realizes

object_properties_isParameterFor.name: isParameterFor
comment: A Concept can have a Parameter that constrains the attributes that a classified Entity can have in a certain Situation, e.g. a 4WheelDriver Role definedIn the ItalianTrafficLaw has a MinimumAge parameter on the Amount 16.
label: is parameter for

object_properties_isTaskOfInputRole.name: isTaskOfInputRole
comment: A relation between a Task and one of its input roles.
label: is task of input role

object_properties_hasLocation.name: hasLocation
comment:
A generic, relative spatial location, holding between any entities. E.g. 'the cat is on the mat', 'Omar is in Samarcanda', 'the wound is close to the femural artery'.
For 'absolute' locations, see SpaceRegion
label: has location

object_properties_isComponentOf.name: isComponentOf
comment: The asymmetric isProperPartOf relation without transitivity, holding between an Object (the system) and another (the component), and assuming a Design that structures the Object.
label: is component of

object_properties_isLinkedTo.name: isLinkedTo
comment: A spatial relation holding between objects that are linked with each other such that they resist spatial separation.
label: is linked to

object_properties_isMovedByAgent.name: isMovedByAgent
comment: A relation from an object to an agent who causes it to move.

object_properties_movesObject.name: movesObject
comment: A relation from an agent to an object that the agent causes to move.

object_properties_isOccurrenceOf.name: isOccurrenceOf
comment: A relation between an event and an event type, e.g. 'taking the cup from the table' is an occurence of the motion 'approaching'.
label: is occurence of

object_properties_isClassifiedBy.name: isClassifiedBy
comment: A relation between a Concept and an Entity, e.g. 'John is considered a typical rude man'; your last concert constitutes the achievement of a lifetime; '20-year-old means she's mature enough'.
label: is classified by

object_properties_isOccurringIn.name: isOccurringIn
comment: A relation between an event and an event type, e.g. 'taking the cup from the table' is an occurence of the motion 'approaching'.
label: is occurring in

object_properties_classifies.name: classifies
comment: A relation between a Concept and an Entity, e.g. the Role 'student' classifies a Person 'John'.
label: classifies

object_properties_isOrderedBy.name: isOrderedBy
comment: The relation between an 'Order item' and the 'Order' that sorts them (via the relations 'precedes' and 'follows')
label: is ordered by

object_properties_orders.name: orders
comment: The relation between an 'Order' and the sorted 'Order item' (sorted via the relations 'precedes' and 'follows' between the 'Order item's)
label: orders

object_properties_isTaskOfOutputRole.name: isTaskOfOutputRole
comment: A relation between a Task and one of its output roles.
label: is task of output role

object_properties_isPerformedBy.name: isPerformedBy
comment: A relation from an Action to the Agent who performs it.
label: is performed by

object_properties_isPhysicallyContainedI.name: isPhysicallyContainedIn
comment: A spatial relation holding between an object (the container), and objects it contains.
label: is physically contained in

object_properties_isPlanFor.name: isPlanFor
comment: A special relation between a Plan and a Task, to indicate that the Plan describes a way to achieve the Task.
label: is plan for

object_properties_isAbout.name: isAbout
comment:
A relation between an information object and an Entity (including information objects). It can be used to talk about entities that are references of proper nouns: the proper noun 'Leonardo da Vinci' isAbout the Person Leonardo da Vinci; as well as to talk about sets of entities that can be described by a common noun: the common noun 'person' isAbout the set of all persons in a domain of discourse, which can be represented in DOLCE-Ultralite as an individual of the class: dul:Collection.
A specific sentence may use common nouns with either a singular or plural reference, or it can even refer to all possible references (e.g. in a lexicographic definition): all those uses are kinds of aboutness.

The isAbout relation is sometimes considered as reflexive, however this is semiotically inaccurate, because information can be about itself ('de dicto' usage, as in 'John is four character long'), but it is typically about something else ('de re' usage, as in 'John loves Mary').
If a reflexivity exists in general, it rather concerns its realisation, which is always associated with an event, e.g. an utterance, which makes the information denoting itself, besides its aboutness. This is implemented in DUL with the dul:realizesSelfInformation property, which is used with local reflexivity in the dul:InformationRealization class.
label: is about

object_properties_isReplacedBy.name: isReplacedBy
comment: The relation between a State that is replaced by another, e.g., the state of a bowl of fruits containing some objects is replaced by a new containment state when one object is taken away (in this example, we simplified the relation between the State and its type).
label: is replaced by

object_properties_replaces.name: replaces
comment: The relation between a State that replaces another, e.g., the state of a bowl of fruits containing some objects is replaced by a new containment state when one object is taken away (in this example, we simplified the relation between the State and its type).
label: replaces

object_properties_hasSetting.name: hasSetting
comment: A relation between entities and situations, e.g. 'this morning I've prepared my coffee with a new fantastic Arabica', i.e.: (an amount of) a new fantastic Arabica hasSetting the preparation of my coffee this morning.
label: has setting

object_properties_isTaskDefinedIn.name: isTaskDefinedIn
comment: A relation between a description and a task, e.g. the task 'boil' is defined in a recipe for a cake.
label: is task defined in

object_properties_isSupportedBy.name: isSupportedBy
comment: A relation between an object (the supporter) and another object (the supportee) where the supporter cancels the effect of gravity on the supportee.
Relates a supportee to one of its supporters.
label: is supported by

object_properties_hasCommonBoundary.name: hasCommonBoundary
comment: A relation to encode either formal or informal characterizations of 'boundaries' common to two different entities: an Event that ends when another begins, two abstract regions that have a common topological boundary, two objects that are said to be 'in contact' from a commonsense perspective, etc.
label: has common boundary

object_properties_supports.name: supports
comment: A relation between an object (the supporter) and another object (the supportee) where the supporter cancels the effect of gravity on the supportee.
Relates a supportee to one of its supporters.

object_properties_isTaskOf.name: isTaskOf
comment: A relation between roles and tasks, e.g. 'students have the duty of giving exams' (i.e. the Role 'student' hasTask the Task 'giving exams').
label: is task of

object_properties_isTerminatedBy.name: isTerminatedBy
comment: The association between an Event that is terminated by another Event, e.g., the Action of picking an apple from a bowl of fruits terminates the State of containment between the apple and the bowl.
label: is terminated by

object_properties_terminates.name: terminates
comment: The association between an Event that terminates another Event, e.g., the Action of picking an apple from a bowl of fruits terminates the State of containment between the apple and the bowl.
label: terminates

object_properties_meets.name: meets
comment: A relation between entities, expressing a 'sequence' schema where one of the entities exactly ends where the other entity starts.

object_properties_metBy.name: metBy
comment: A relation between entities, expressing a 'sequence' schema where one of the entities exactly ends where the other entity starts.
label: met by

object_properties_overlappedBy.name: overlappedBy
comment: A schematic relation between any entities that also implies ordering, e.g. "she has worked into the night".
label: overlapped by

object_properties_overlappedOn.name: overlappedOn
comment: A schematic relation between any entities that also implies ordering, e.g. "she has worked into the night".
label: overlapped on

object_properties_simultaneous.name: simultaneous
comment: `A simultaneous B` means that A strictly starts and ends at the same time instant as B, i.e. their temporal extend is equal.

object_properties_startedBy.name: startedBy
comment: `A starts B` means that A starts exactly where B starts, and that A strictly ends before B. As in "I start my day with a coffee".
label: started by

object_properties_starts.name: starts
comment: `A starts B` means that A starts exactly where B starts, and that A strictly ends before B. As in "I start my day with a coffee".

object_properties_transitionsBack.name: transitionsBack
comment: A property which relates a Transient to an Object it both changes from and changes into. This is useful to model objects which, through participation in a process, transform themselves so that an ontological reclassification is necessary, however this transformation is reversible and at the end of the process the objects revert to their previous kind. An example of this is catalysts in chemistry.
label: transitions back

object_properties_transitionsFrom.name: transitionsFrom
comment: A property which relates a Transient to an Object it changes from. This is useful to model objects which, through participation in a process, transform themselves so that an ontological reclassification is necessary. An example of this is dough undergoing the Maillard reaction through baking.
label: transitions from

object_properties_transitionsTo.name: transitionsTo
comment: A property which relates a Transient to an Object it changes into. This is useful to model objects which, through participation in a process, transform themselves so that an ontological reclassification is necessary. An example of this is baked dough eventually becoming bread by completing a baking process.
label: transitions to

object_properties_hasExpectedTerminalSit.name: hasExpectedTerminalSituation
comment: A relation between a Transition and the Situation it is expected to, and does actually, end at. You can assert this relationship when the observed outcome of a transition matches expectations.
label: has expected terminal situation

object_properties_hasPostcondition.name: hasPostcondition
comment: This should be taken to mean that the postcondition is the situation expected to follow the current situation. Whether the expectation is met is another issue.

Direct succession applied to situations. 
E.g., 'A postcondition of our Plan is to have things settled'.
label: has postcondition

object_properties_hasRequiredInitialSitu.name: hasRequiredInitialSituation
comment: A relationship between a Situation x and another Situation y that precedes it, such that without y manifesting, it would be impossible for x to manifest.
label: has required initial situation

object_properties_hasPrecondition.name: hasPrecondition
comment: This should be taken to mean: a precondition is a situation without which the current situation would not be possible.

Direct precedence applied to situations. 
E.g., 'A precondition to declare war against a foreign country is claiming to find nuclear weapons in it'.
label: has precondition

object_properties_manifestsIn.name: manifestsIn
comment: A relationship indicating that a Situation is realized in an Event that actually happened.
label: manifests in

object_properties_preventedBy.name: preventedBy
comment: A relationship indicating a Situation is prevented by another from manifesting.
label: prevented by

object_properties_prevents.name: prevents
comment: A relationship indicating that a situation does or would prevent another from manifesting. Useful for reasoning about planning (what to do to avoid some bad outcome) and failure recovery (what aspects of the world state prevent continuing the plan?).
label: prevents

object_properties_actsFor.name: actsFor
comment: The relation holding between any Agent, and a SocialAgent. In principle, a SocialAgent requires at least one PhysicalAgent in order to act, but this dependency can be 'delegated'; e.g. a university can be acted for by a department, which on its turm is acted for by physical agents.
label: acts for

object_properties_executesTask.name: executesTask
comment: A relation between an action and a task, e.g. 'putting some water in a pot and putting the pot on a fire until the water starts bubbling' executes the task 'boiling'.
label: executes task

object_properties_expresses.name: expresses
comment:
A relation between an InformationObject and a 'meaning', generalized here as a 'SocialObject'. For example: 'A Beehive is a structure in which bees are kept, typically in the form of a dome or box.' (Oxford dictionary)'; 'the term Beehive expresses the concept Beehive in my apiculture ontology'.
The intuition for 'meaning' is intended to be very broad. A separate, large comment is included for those who want to investigate more on what kind of meaning can be represented in what form.

This is a large comment field for those who want to investigate the different uses of the 'expresses' relation for modeling different approaches to meaning characterization and modeling.
For example, in all these cases, some aspect of meaning is involved:

- Beehive means "a structure in which bees are kept, typically in the form of a dome or box." (Oxford dictionary)
- 'Beehive' is a synonym in noun synset 09218159 "beehive|hive" (WordNet)
- 'the term Beehive can be interpreted as the fact of 'being a beehive', i.e. a relation that holds for concepts such as Bee, Honey, Hosting, etc.'
- 'the text of Italian apiculture regulation expresses a rule by which beehives should be kept at least one kilometer away from inhabited areas'
- 'the term Beehive expresses the concept Beehive'
- ''Beehive' for apiculturists does not express the same meaning as for, say, fishermen'
- 'Your meaning of 'Beautiful' does not seem to fit mine'
- ''Beehive' is formally interpreted as the set of all beehives'
- 'from the term 'Beehive', we can build a vector space of statistically significant cooccurring terms in the documents that contain it'
- the lexeme 'Belly' expresses the role 'Body_Part' in the frame 'ObservableBodyParts' (FrameNet)

As the examples suggest, the 'meaning of meaning' is dependent on the background approach/theory that one assumes. One can hardly make a summary of the too many approaches and theories of meaning, therefore this relation is maybe the most controversial and difficult to explain; normally, in such cases it would be better to give up formalizing. 
However, the usefulness of having a 'semantic abstraction' in modeling information objects is so high (e.g. for the semantic web, interoperability, reengineering, etc.), that we accept this challenging task, although without taking any particular position in the debate. 
We provide here some examples, which we want to generalize upon when using the 'expresses' relation to model semantic aspects of social reality.

In the most common approach, lexicographers that write dictionaries, glossaries, etc. assume that the meaning of a term is a paraphrase (or 'gloss', or 'definition'). 
Another approach is provided by concept schemes like thesauri and lexicons, which assume that the meaning of a term is a 'concept', encoded as a 'lemma', 'synset', or 'descriptor'.
Still another approach is that of psychologists and cognitive scientists, which often assume that the meaning of an information object is a concept encoded in the mind or cognitive system of an agent. 
A radically different approach is taken by social scientists and semioticians, who usually assume that meanings of an information object are spread across the communication practices in which members of a community use that object.
Another approach that tackles the distributed nature of meaning is assumed by geometrical models of semantics, which assume that the meaning of an InformationObject (e.g. a word) results from the set of informational contexts (e.g. within texts) in which that object is used similarly.
The logical approach to meaning is still different, since it assumes that the meaning of e.g. a term is equivalent to the set of individuals that the term can be applied to; for example, the meaning of 'Ali' is e.g. an individual person called Ali, the meaning of 'Airplane' is e.g. the set of airplanes, etc. 
Finally, an approach taken by structuralist linguistics and frame semantics is that a meaning is the relational context in which an information object can be applied; for example, a meaning of 'Airplane' is situated e.g. in the context ('frame') of passenger airline flights.

These different approaches are not necessarily conflicting, and they mostly talk about different aspects of so-called 'semantics'. They can be summarized and modelled within DOLCE-Ultralite as follows (notice that such list is far from exhaustive):

(1) Informal meaning (as for linguistic or commonsense semantics: a distinction is assumed between (informal) meaning and reference; see isAbout for an alternative pattern on reference)
	- Paraphrase meaning (as for lexicographic semantics). Here it is modelled as the expresses relation between instances of InformationObject and different instances of InformationObject that act as 'paraphrases'
	- Conceptual meaning (as for 'concept scheme' semantics). Here it is modelled as the expresses relation between instances of InformationObject and instances of Concept
	- Relational meaning (as for frame semantics). Here it is modelled as the expresses relation between instances of InformationObject and instances of Description
	- Cognitive meaning (as for 'psychological' semantics). Here it is modelled as the expresses relation between any instance of InformationObject and any different instance of InformationObject that isRealizedBy a mental, cognitive or neural state (depending on which theory of mind is assumed). Such states can be considered here as instances of Process (occurring in the mind, cognitive system, or neural system of an agent)
	- Cultural meaning (as for 'social science' semantics). Here it is modelled as the expresses relation between instances of InformationObject and instances of SocialObject (institutions, cultural paradigms, norms, social practices, etc.)
	- Distributional meaning (as for geometrical models of meaning). Here it is modelled as the expresses relation between any instance of InformationObject and any different instance of InformationObject that isFormallyRepresentedIn some (geometrical) Region (e.g. a vector space)

(2) Formal meaning (as for logic and formal semantics: no distinction is assumed between informal meaning and reference, therefore between 'expresses' and 'isAbout', which can be used interchangeably)
	- Object-level formal meaning (as in the traditional first-order logic semantics). Here it is modelled as the expresses relation between an instance of InformationObject and an instance of Collection that isGroundingFor (in most cases) a Set; isGroundingFor is defined in the ontology: http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/dul/IOLite.owl
	- Modal formal meaning (as in possible-world semantics). Here it is modelled as the expresses relation between an instance of InformationObject and an instance of Collection that isGroundingFor a Set, and which isPartOf some different instance of Collection that isGroundingFor a PossibleWorld

This is only a first step to provide a framework, in which one can model different aspects of meaning. A more developed ontology should approach the problem of integrating the different uses of 'expresses', so that different theories, resources, methods can interoperate.
label: expresses

object_properties_isExecutedIn.name: isExecutedIn
comment: A relation between an action and a task, e.g. 'putting some water in a pot and putting the pot on a fire until the water starts bubbling' executes the task 'boiling'.
label: is executed in

object_properties_isExpressedBy.name: isExpressedBy
comment:
A relation between a dul:SocialObject (the 'meaning') and a dul:InformationObject (the 'expression'). 
For example: 'A Beehive is a structure in which bees are kept, typically in the form of a dome or box.' (Oxford dictionary)'; 'the term Beehive expresses the concept Beehive in my apiculture ontology'.
The intuition for 'meaning' is intended to be very broad. A separate, large comment is included in the encoding of 'expresses', for those who want to investigate more on what kind of meaning can be represented in what form.
label: is expressed by

object_properties_isPartOf.name: isPartOf
comment: A relation between any entities, e.g. 'brain is a part of the human body'. See dul:hasPart for additional documentation.
label: is part of

object_properties_satisfies.name: satisfies
comment: A relation between a Situation and a Description, e.g. the execution of a Plan satisfies that plan.
label: satisfies

data_properties_hasColorValue.name: hasColorValue
comment: Associates a ColorRegion to numerical data describing the color.
label: has color value

data_properties_hasRegionDataValue.name: hasRegionDataValue
comment: A datatype property that encodes values for a Region, e.g. a float for the Region Height.
label: has region data value

data_properties_hasDataFormat.name: hasDataFormat
comment: A property linking an InformationRealization to a string specifying a format name, e.g. URDF or STL.

data_properties_hasDataValue.name: hasDataValue
comment:
A datatype property that encodes values from a datatype for an Entity. 
There are several ways to encode values in DOLCE (Ultralite):

1) Directly assert an xsd:_ value to an Entity by using hasDataValue
2) Assert a Region for an Entity by using hasRegion, and then assert an xsd:_ value to that Region, by using hasRegionDataValue
3) Assert a Quality for an Entity by using hasQuality, then assert a Region for that Quality, and assert an xsd:_ value to that Region, by using hasRegionDataValue
4) When the value is required, but not directly observed, assert a Parameter for an xsd:_ value by using hasParameterDataValue, and then associate the Parameter to an Entity by using isConstraintFor
5) When the value is required, but not directly observed, you can also assert a Parameter for a Region by using parametrizes, and then assert an xsd:_ value to that Region, by using hasRegionDataValue

The five approaches obey different requirements. 
For example, a simple value can be easily asserted by using pattern (1), but if one needs to assert an interval between two values, a Region should be introduced to materialize that interval, as pattern (2) suggests. 
Furthermore, if one needs to distinguish the individual Quality of a value, e.g. the particular nature of the density of a substance, pattern (3) can be used. 
Patterns (4) and (5) should be used instead when a constraint or a selection is modeled, independently from the actual observation of values in the real world.
label: has data value

data_properties_hasDepth.name: hasDepth
comment: The depth of a shape.
label: has depth

data_properties_hasShapeParameter.name: hasShapeParameter
comment: Associates a SpaceRegion to some parameter value describing its shape. This is a fairly generic property, and to capture the semantics of the information associated to the SpaceRegion, its more specific subproperties should be used.
label: has shape parameter

data_properties_hasEventBegin.name: hasEventBegin
comment: A relation recording when an Event started. In this case, we think of the Event as something unfolding over some span of time.
label: has event begin

data_properties_hasEventTime.name: hasEventTime
comment: Superproperty of hasEventBegin and hasEventEnd, records that an Event happened, or was happening, at a particular time. Using the subproperties captures the richer semantics of that time relative to the event. Using only this superproperty may be appropriate when the Event is construed to take place at a single instant of time.
label: has event time

data_properties_hasEventEnd.name: hasEventEnd
comment: A relation recording when an Event ended. In this case, we think of the Event as something unfolding over some span of time.
label: has event end

data_properties_hasFilePath.name: hasFilePath
comment: Associates an entity to some file containing data about it. For example, can be used to describe physical objects via a mesh file.
label: has file path

data_properties_hasForceValue.name: hasForceValue
comment: A value that quantifies a force given in Newton.
label: has force value

data_properties_hasFrictionValue.name: hasFrictionValue
comment: The coefficient of friction denotes the ratio of friction force between touching objects. The coefficient is dimensionless.
label: has friction value

data_properties_hasHSVValue.name: hasHSVValue
comment: Associates a ColorRegion to numerical data describing the color. This data uses the Hue-Saturation-Value color space.
label: has hsv value

data_properties_hasHeight.name: hasHeight
comment: The height of a shape.
label: has height

data_properties_hasIntervalBegin.name: hasIntervalBegin
comment: A relation recording when some TimeInterval started.
label: has interval begin

data_properties_hasIntervalTime.name: hasIntervalTime
comment: Superproperty of relations used to connect moments in time to a TimeInterval.
label: has interval time

data_properties_hasIntervalEnd.name: hasIntervalEnd
comment: A relation recording when a TimeInterval ended.
label: has interval end

data_properties_hasJointEffort.name: hasJointEffort
comment: The effort applied in a joint given in N (prismatic joint) or N*m (hinged joints).
label: has joint effort

data_properties_hasJointParameter.name: hasJointParameter
comment: Assigns a value for an attribute of a joint.
label: has joint parameter

data_properties_hasJointEffortLimit.name: hasJointEffortLimit
comment: The maximum effort applied in a joint given in N (prismatic joint) or N*m (hinged joints).
label: has joint effort limit

data_properties_hasJointPosition.name: hasJointPosition
comment: The position of a joint given in m (prismatic joints) or rad (hinged joints).
label: has joint position

data_properties_hasJointPositionMax.name: hasJointPositionMax
comment: The maximum position of a joint given in m (prismatic joints) or rad (hinged joints).
label: has joint position max

data_properties_hasJointPositionMin.name: hasJointPositionMin
comment: The minimum position of a joint given in m (prismatic joints) or rad (hinged joints).
label: has joint position min

data_properties_hasJointVelocity.name: hasJointVelocity
comment: The velocity of a joint given in m/s (prismatic joints) or rad/s (hinged joints).
label: has joint velocity

data_properties_hasJointVelocityLimit.name: hasJointVelocityLimit
comment: The maximum velocity of a joint given in m/s (prismatic joints) or rad/s (hinged joints).
label: has joint velocity limit

data_properties_hasLength.name: hasLength
comment: The length of a shape.
label: has length

data_properties_hasMassValue.name: hasMassValue
comment: The mass value of a physical object in kilogram.
label: has mass value

data_properties_hasNameString.name: hasNameString
comment: A relation recording some identifier associated to an Entity.
label: has name string

data_properties_hasPersistentIdentifier.name: hasPersistentIdentifier
comment: A property linking an InformationRealization to a persistent identifier such as a DOI, which can then be used to obtain an address at which the realization (i.e. digital file) can be retrieved.

data_properties_hasPositionData.name: hasPositionData
comment: Associates a spatial region to a position.
label: has position data

data_properties_hasSpaceParameter.name: hasSpaceParameter
comment: Associates a SpaceRegion to some parameter value describing it. This is a fairly generic property, and to capture the semantics of the information associated to the SpaceRegion, its more specific subproperties should be used.
label: has space parameter

data_properties_hasPriority.name: hasPriority
comment: A relation asserting some entity has a particular priority.

data_properties_hasRGBValue.name: hasRGBValue
comment: Associates a ColorRegion to numerical data describing the color. This data uses the Red-Green-Blue color space.
label: has rgb value

data_properties_hasRadius.name: hasRadius
comment: The radius of a circular or oval shape.
label: has radius

data_properties_hasReferenceFrame.name: hasReferenceFrame
comment: Gives the name associated to the local coordinate frame of a SpaceRegion.
label: has reference frame

data_properties_hasShapeScale.name: hasShapeScale
comment:
The scale of a shape, given as a vector of three real numbers to adjust x, y, z components of vertex vectors. In cases where a shape needs to be flipped compared to the shape described by a mesh, one of the scale components will be negative. 

It is often the case that shapes need to be altered from their description in a shape file, and a typical example of this is scaling a mesh. 

In robotics, it is not uncommon to encounter shapes that are flipped compared to the shape in a mesh file. This is because robots often have bilateral symmetry, thus it makes sense to reuse the same meshes for corresponding links of the left and right arms.
label: has shape scale

data_properties_hasWidth.name: hasWidth
comment: The width of a shape.
label: has width

data_properties_isReificationOf.name: isReificationOf
comment: An auxiliary property that is used to generate object individuals, called reifications, from any other Entity, e.g. from relations, classes, data types. These reifications can then be used in DL axioms as any other named individual.
label: is reification of

annotation_properties_UsageGuideline.name: UsageGuideline
comment:
Provides a definition, or usage guideline, aimed at a particular community of the ontology's users. The community is identified by the subproperty of UsageGuideline.

A style recommendation for usage guidelines is that they should be brief. In contrast to usual concept annotations that can, and should be detailed about the reasons behind modelling decisions, usage guidelines are simply meant to answer questions about when it is appropriate to use a concept, and they must be a practical, easy to query and understand resource.

annotation_properties_nickname.name: nickname
comment: Similar to rdfs:label, but without GUI or reasoner impact in Protege; avoiding Protege problems is why this is not a label subproperty. Nicknames are used by particular software working with the ontology as a way to give community-specific names to concepts. Communities are identified by the subproperty of nickname.

annotation_properties_symbol.name: symbol
comment: An annotation property which should be used to record by what symbols or abbreviations, if any, some relation or entity is known in scientific literature.
